MATH5315M: Applied probability & statistics - HTML Version of module Lecture Notes

The aim of this module is to learn the most important concepts in probability theory and statistics, and to introduce and develop a number of methods in statistics usually used in applied financial analysis. On completion of the module, you will be expected to be able to communicate the theoretical and applied concepts of probability and statistics, and to carry out statistical tests and interpret the findings. The material can be split into three sections: fundamentals of probability and statistics, simple statistical analyses and time series methods.

The notes in this document are not exhaustive and should be supplemented with additional information from both the lectures and the recommended reading. Each chapter of the notes has been linked with chapters from the recommended reading to help with this. Throughout the notes there are examples that will be discussed in the lectures, and you will be expected to take notes covering the examples. Additional examples not in these notes will also be explained in the lectures.

In the notes, the mention of the implementation of the techniques in a computer-based statistical package has been kept to a minimum. However, you must bear in mind that we will be investigating how we can run these analyses on specific datasets. In the second half of the module, some of our focus will be on implementation in a statistical package called R. We use R because it

  • • is rich enough to handle all the techniques we cover in this module
  • • can be used to do more advanced analyses that you will be facing later in the programme
  • • is free and available on many operating systems, and
  • • is versatile enough for new methods to be easily created (which might be important in your future careers).

Martín López-García (September, 2019)

1 Data Summaries - (CT3 Unit 1)

Data exist in many different forms, and we need to understand the differences to perform useful statistical analyses. Often, simple statistical summaries and well-made graphs can remove the need for complicated (and sometimes expensive) analysis.

1.1 Types of Data

Batch data are a set of related observations.
Sample data are a set of observations that are chosen to be representative of some population.

Numerical (quantitative) - Discrete {0,1,2,3,…}⁢or⁢{12,1,2,4}
                                             Continuous, e.g. height
Categorical (qualitative) - Attribute (dichotomous or binary, e.g., yes/no)
                                            Nominal (e.g. colour) - “no order”
                                            Ordinal (e.g. agree, disagree, don’t care…)

1.2 Data summaries

There many ways to display data: bar charts, 3D bar charts, pie charts, grouped frequency tables, histograms, stem and leaf diagrams, dot and line plots, line plots and box plots (to name some common types).

Example 1
Dataset: 18, 18, 19, 22, 22, 23, 25, 25, 25, 28, 30, 31, 33, 37, 41.

Stem and leaf diagram of ages

1|889

2|2235558

3|0137

4|1

Key: 3|2 denotes 32 years old.

Example 2
Dataset: 18, 18, 19, 22, 22, 23, 25, 25, 25, 28, 30, 31, 33, 37, 41.

Show bar chart using same intervals and talk about relative frequency.

Interval Count Relative frequency
15- 3 0.6
20- 3 0.6
25- 4 0.8
30- 4 0.4
40-50 1 0.1

Draw histogram.


Bimodality - when data has 2 modes.

Multimodality - when data has more than 2 modes.

We can also make numerical (rather than graphical) summaries of a dataset.

For a set of n observations, x1,x2,…,xn, the mean is defined by:

x¯=1n⁢∑i=1nxi.

The median is the ‘middle’ observation in a data set which has been sorted. If n is odd, it is the n+12th observation. If n is even, it is the mid point between n2th⁢and⁢n+22th observation.

The mode of a dataset is the value that occurs most frequently.

The mean, median and mode are all measures of location.

The range is the difference between the largest and smallest values in a data set:

R=max𝑖⁢(xi)-min𝑖⁢(xi).

The interquartile range is the difference between the upper and lower quartiles: IQR = UQ - LQ, where the lower quartile is the 25⁢t⁢h percentile, and the upper quartile is the 75⁢t⁢h precentile (see below).

A box plot is a useful visualisation tool that shows the LQ, IQR and UQ.

Percentiles extend the idea of quartiles. For example, the 5th percentile is the value such that 5% of the data falls below it. The nearest rank method for calculating the rank at which the Pth-percentile will occur uses the formula:

n=⌈P100×N⌉

where N is the total number of observations. We equate the nth observation with the Pth-percentile.

There are other methods like linear interpolation

Example 3
Given a dataset: 0, 2, 3, 8 and 7.
We have median value 3.
Including 3, we have LQ = 2 and UQ =7.
We have IQR = 5 - there is a lot of data in the range.
Produce a box plot.
What is the 30th percentile?
n=⌈30100⁢5⌉=2. The second value in the ordered set is 2.

Note, when using computer programs to show box plots - make sure outliers are plotted on the line. L(U)Q -(+) 1.5*IQR.

For a dataset x1,…,xn, with mean x¯, we consider deviations from the mean:

∑i=1n(xi-x¯)2⁢ [the sum of squared deviations from the mean].

We define the sample variance to be:

s2=1n-1⁢∑i=1n(xi-x¯)2,

and the sample standard deviation is:

s=s2.

Most of the data falls in (x¯-3⁢s,x¯+3⁢s).

The range, IQR, variance and standard deviation are all measures of spread.

Example 4
Consider the following frequency table:
Result Frequency Cumulative Frequency
1 10 10
2 12 22
3 15 37
4 18 55
5 25 80
6 10 90
7 5 95
The range is (7-1)=6.
The median is at the 48th observation: 4.
The LQ is at the 24th obs: 3.
The UQ is at the 72nd obs: 5.
The IQR is (5-3) = 2. (Data concentrated around median because IQR < Range/2.)
The variance is 2.79 (to 2 d.p.) and the std. deviation is 1.67

2 Introduction to Probability - (CT3 Unit 2)

2.1 Definitions

The sample space 𝒮 (for a well-defined experiment) is the set of all possible outcomes that might be observed.

An event A is defined as a subset of 𝒮 (A ⊆ 𝒮).

A complementary event can be denoted by

Ac (or A′,A¯,⌝A)

and is the subset of 𝒮 with all possible events not included in A.

Intersection: Given two events A and B, their intersection A∩B denotes the set
                  where both A and B occur.

Union:        Given two events A and B, their union A∪B denotes the set
                  where A and/or B occur.

Example 5
Imagine rolling a six-sided die.
𝒮={1⁢ is on top,2⁢ is on top,3,4,5,6}
The event that we have an even number on top is {2,4,6}, which is a subset of 𝒮. The complementary event is {1,3,5}, which is also subset of 𝒮.
The event that we have a number less than 1 on top is ∅, which is a subset of 𝒮. The complementary event is 𝒮, which is a rather boring subset of 𝒮.

The null set (denoted ∅) is the empty set; that is, the set with no elements.

2.2 Basic probability axioms

I.      P(𝒮) = 1, the probability of something happening is 1.
II.     P(A) ≥0⁢∀ A ⊂ 𝒮, probability of something happening is non-negative.
III.    If A and B are mutually exclusive events: P(A∪B) = P(A)+P⁢(B).

Powerpoint: Unit2_Support.pptx

P(A)c = 1 - P(A)

𝒮 = A∪Ac      P(𝒮) = P(A) + P(Ac)

𝒮c=∅, complement of 𝒮 is empty, because there is no event.

P(A∪B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A∩B)

2.3 Conditional Probability

Consider two events, A and B. We might want to know the probability of event A occurring given that B has occurred. This is known as a conditional probability and is denoted by P⁢(A|B).

P(A|B) = P(A∩B)P(A∩B)+P(Ac∩B)=P(A∩B)P(B)

P(A∩B) = P(A|B)P(B)

For all of these, P(B) > 0, otherwise B cannot happen.

P(A) = P(A∩𝒮)P⁢(𝒮) = P(A|𝒮)

Example 6
Imagine rolling a fair six-sided die again. What is the probability of getting a two given that you have got an even number? P⁢(2|even)=P⁢(2⁢ and even)P⁢(even)=1/3.

A and B are independent ⇔ P⁢(A|B)=P⁢(A)
⇔ P⁢(A∩B)=P⁢(A)⁢P⁢(B)
⇔ P⁢(B|A)=P⁢(B)

Example 7
Is the event of rolling a 5 or a 6 (A) independent of the event of rolling an even number (B)?

P⁢(A)=1/3,P⁢(B)=1/2,P⁢(A∩B)=1/6,
P⁢(A|B)=1/3⁢ and ⁢P⁢(B|A)=1/2.

What about the event of rolling a 3 or a 5 (C) and the event of rolling an odd number (D)? \hdashline

2.4 Theorem of total probability

We have a space 𝒮 divided into a partition of n mutually exclusive events. For example,

𝒮={1,2,3,4,5,6},with,
E1={1,2,3},E2={4}⁢ and E3={5,6}.

All outcomes are accounted for, but do not occur more than once:

Ei∩Ej=∅⁢ if ⁢i≠j
E1∪E2∪…∪En=𝒮.

For any event, A ⊂ 𝒮:

A=(A∩E1)∪(A∩E2)∪…∪(A∩En)

Therefore,

P(A)=∑j=1nP(A∩Ej)=∑j=1nP(A|Ej)P(Ej).

Example 8
I am interested in the probability of Man Utd winning the Champions’ League. After some thought, I propose

P⁢(Win|no sig. injuries, no new signings) = 0.2,
P⁢(Win|sig. injuries, no new signings) = 0.05,
P⁢(Win|no sig. injuries, new signings) = 0.25,
P⁢(Win|sig. injuries, new signings) = 0.18.

What is my overall probability of Man Utd winning the Champions’ League? This depends on what I think the chances are of each of the events that are being conditioned on. Suppose:

P⁢(no sig. injuries, no new signings) = 0.4,
P⁢(sig. injuries, no new signings) = 0.05,
P⁢(no sig. injuries, new signings) = 0.2.

Note that the events here are mutually exclusive. Now, by the theory of total probability,

P⁢(Win) = 0.2×0.4+0.05×0.05+0.25×0.2+0.18×0.35
= 0.1955.

2.5 Bayes Theorem

Draw rectangle to describe partition and relation to A.

Let E1, E2, …, En be partitions of 𝒮 and let A ⊂ 𝒮, then:

1) P(E|iA) = P(Ei∩A)P(A)  ∀i

2) P(E∩iA) = P(A∩Ei) = P(Ej)P(A|Ej)

3) P(A) = ∑j=1nP(A∩Ej)

Thus,

P(E|iA)=P(Ei)P(A|Ei)∑j=1nP(Ej)P(A|Ej)

Example 9
A financial think-tank has speculated that the probability of a major bank collapse in the next ten years is 0.5 if there is no substantial government-imposed regulation and that the probability of a major bank collapse in the next ten years is 0.2 if there is substantial government-imposed regulation. Currently, it is thought that there is a 50% chance of further, substantial government-imposed regulation.
If we do not see a major bank collapse in the next ten years, what is the probability that there has been substantial government regulation?
First, let B be the event that a major bank collapses in the next ten years, and let G be the event that there is substantial government-imposed regulation.
From the above statements, we have

P⁢(B|Gc)=0.5,P⁢(B|G)=0.2⁢ and ⁢P⁢(G)=P⁢(Gc)=0.5.

We are interested in

P⁢(G|Bc) = P⁢(Bc|G)⁢P⁢(G)P⁢(Bc|G)⁢P⁢(G)+P⁢(Bc|Gc)⁢P⁢(Gc)⁢ (using Bayes’s theorem)
= 0.8×0.50.8×0.5+0.5×0.5=0.62⁢ (to 2 d.p.).

3 Random Variables (CT3 Unit 3)

3.1 Definition

Formally, a random variable is a rule for associating a number with each element in a sample space. If w is an element of 𝒮 and we associate the number x with w, then X⁢(w)=x.

For example, 𝒮 is a countably infinite set:

{0,1,2,3,…}    or,
{x:x=y2,y=…-3,-2,-1,0,1,2,3,…}.

These both correspond to discrete random variables.

Probabilities are defined over the elements of 𝒮, but shorthand is used in terms of the random variable such that P(X=x).

Example 10
Given 8 outcomes: w1,…,w8. We are interested in three events:
w1,w2,w3 are considered as a single event, w4 and w5 are considered as a single event and w6,w7,w8 also.
Associate x1 with event {w1,w2,w3} and x2 with {w4,w5},
by P(X=x1), it is meant P(E1),
by P(X=x2), it is meant P(E2),       E2 = {w4,w5}.

3.2 Probability Functions

The function fX(x) = P(X=x), ∀x in the range of the random variable, is called the probability function. These are requirements for this function:

fX⁢(x) ≥ 0   ∀x,
∑xfX⁢(x) = 1

The function FX⁢(x) = P(X≤x) ∀x∈ℝ.FX(x) is a monotonically increasing function, and it has maximum value of 1.

For discrete random variables with gaps of 1,

P(X=x)=FX(x)-FX(x-1).

The range of a continuous random variable is an interval (or collection of intervals) on ℝ. For continuous functions, there are infinitely many probabilities so we consider the density of the probability through a probability density function (pdf). The probability associated with an interval (a,b) is represented as P(a<X<b) = P(a≤X≤b).

Probabilities are evaluated by integrating the pdf, fX⁢(x).

⟹ P(a<X<b)=∫abfX(x) dx

The requirements for fX⁢(x) to be a pdf are:

fX⁢(x) ≥ 0   ∀   x∈ℝ,
∫-∞∞fX⁢(x)⁢𝑑x = 1.

The cumulative distribution function (cdf) is defined as FX⁢(x) = P(X≤x). For a continuous random variable, this is a monotonically increasing function and is defined  ∀ x∈ℝ:

FX(x)=P(-∞<X<x)=∫-∞xfX(t)dt.

Example 11
Suppose we have the following function: f(x)=2x (if 0≤x≤0.25), x2+3/16 (if 0.25≤x≤1), 0 (otherwise).
Is it a pdf?
First, f⁢(x)≥0⁢∀x.

∫-∞∞f⁢(x)⁢𝑑x = ∫00.252⁢x⁢𝑑x+∫0.251x2+3/16⁢d⁢x
= [x2]00.25+[x3/3+(3/16)⁢x]0.251
= 102/192≠1.

3.3 Expected Values

3.3.1 Mean

The mean is a measure of location for a random variable.

E[X] is the expectation of the random variable of X.

E[X] is calculated using sums if the RV is discrete, or integrals if continuous.
For the discrete case,

E⁢[X]=∑xx⁢fX⁢(x).

For the continuous case,

E⁢[X]=∫-∞∞x⁢fX⁢(x)⁢𝑑x.

Example 12
If X is the random variable associated with a roll of a fair die, we have {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6},    P(X=x)=16   ∀x,    P(X=x) = fX⁢(x), thus, E[X]=216 = 3.5.


Example 13
Suppose we have random variable X with pdf f(x)=3x2 (if 0≤x≤1), 0 (otherwise).
What is E⁢(X)?

E⁢(X) = ∫01x×3⁢x2⁢𝑑x=∫013⁢x3⁢𝑑x
= [(3/4)⁢x4]01=3/4.

Perhaps draw pdf.

3.3.2 Functions of random variables

For functions of random variables,

E⁢[g⁢(X)]=∑xg⁢(x)⁢fX⁢(x)   [discrete],
E⁢[g⁢(X)]=∫-∞∞g⁢(x)⁢fX⁢(x)⁢𝑑x   [continuous].

Example 14
X -1 0 1 2 3 4
p(X) 1/2 1/4 1/16 1/16 1/16 1/16

E⁢(X)=-12+1016=18=0.125.
What is E⁢(X2)? (Add X2 to table)
E⁢(X2)=916+416+916+1616=3816=15264=2.375.
Note that E⁢(X2)≠E⁢(X)2:
E⁢(X)2=(18)2=164=0.015625.

3.4 Variance

Variance is a measure of uncertainty about a random variable.

Var⁢(X) = E⁢[(X-E⁢(X))2]
= E⁢[X2]-{E⁢[X]}2

Demonstrate this - expand quadratic and use linear properties.

The standard deviation of X is then given by Var⁢(X).

Notation

Population mean: E[X]=μ
Population variance: Var(X)=σ2
Population standard deviation: σ

3.5 Linear Functions

Let the random variable Y=a⁢X+b,a,b∈ℝ and E[X]=μ, then

E⁢[Y] = E⁢[a⁢X+b]
= E⁢[a⁢X]+E⁢[b]
= a⁢E⁢[X]+b
= a⁢μ+b

and

Var⁢(Y) = Var⁢[a⁢X+b]
= Var⁢[a⁢X]+Var⁢[b]
= a2⁢Var⁢[X]
= a2⁢σ2.

Show why a and a2.

Standardisation:

                      Z = (X-μ)σ    (μ⁢ and ⁢σ⁢ are fixed for a random variable)
then    E⁢[Z] = E⁢[X-μσ]
= 1σ⁢(E⁢[X]-μ)=0.
            Var⁢(Z) = 1σ2⁢Var⁢(X)=1.

3.6 Taylor Series approximation (not in CT3)

For any real-valued function g⁢(x), we can write the function as an infinite series (expanding about x=a):

g⁢(x)=g⁢(a)+g′⁢(a)⁢(x-a)1!+g′′⁢(a)⁢(x-a)22!+…+g(n)⁢(x-a)nn!+…

Let Y=g⁢(X),E⁢[X]=μ,Var⁢(X)=σ2 and we can approximate the mean and variance of the transformed variable Y.

Use a Taylor series expansion of g(.) about μ:

E⁢[Y] ≈ g⁢(μ)+12⁢σ2⁢g′′⁢(μ),
Var⁢(Y) ≈ σ2⁢(g′⁢(μ))2.

Example 15
Let X be a random variable with E⁢(X)=2 and Var⁢(X)=1.
Consider the random variable Y=exp⁡(-X2).
What are the mean and variance of Y?

g⁢(x) = exp⁡(-x2),
g′⁢(x) = d⁢exp⁡(y)d⁢y⁢-d⁢x2d⁢x   (using the chain rule, y=-x2)
         = -2⁢x⁢exp⁡(-x2),
g′′⁢(x) = -2⁢x⁢d⁢exp⁡(-x2)d⁢x+-d⁢2⁢xd⁢x⁢exp⁡(-x2)   (using the product rule)
          = 4⁢x2⁢exp⁡(-x2)-2⁢exp⁡(x2).

Now, using the TS approximation,

E⁢(Y) ≈ exp⁡(-4)+0.5×1×(16⁢exp⁡(-4)-2⁢exp⁡(-4))
          = 8⁢exp⁡(-4)=0.147⁢ (to 3 d.p.),
Var⁢(Y) ≈ 1×(-4⁢exp⁡(-4))2=16⁢exp⁡(-8)=0.0054⁢ (to 4 d.p.).

Note that exp⁡(-4)≈0.0183.

3.7 Moments (CT3 Units 1 and 3)

Moments are calculated from datasets or probability distributions for random variables. They give us a way of describing the key features of data or random variables. We have covered much of this already focussing on two of the moments and using a different notation. It is worth revisiting these looking from the perspective of moments because they give us an alternative way to describe both data and random variables.

3.7.1 Moments for a dataset (sample moments)

The mean and variance are special cases of the moments of a dataset. In general, the kt⁢h order moment about a value α is defined by:

mk⁢(α)=1n⁢∑i=1n(xi-α)k

If k=1, and α=0, then mk⁢(α)=x¯,

Therefore, m1⁢(0) = x¯=m1′ (1st raw moment — raw denotes moment about 0)
and the variance s2=nn-1⁢m2⁢(x¯).

Often, we write

m2(x¯)=m2      (m1′=m1)

So, mk is the kt⁢h moment about the sample mean and mk′ is the kt⁢h raw moment (i.e. about zero).

The first four moments are related to the following:
m1 - location,
m2 - spread,
m3 - skewness,
m4 - kurtosis.

A measure for skewness is given by:

g1=m3m23/2     (coefficient of skewness)

The sign of g1 gives the direction of the skew.

3.7.2 Moments for a random variable

Again, the mean and variance are special cases of moments for random variables. In general, the kt⁢h order moment about the value of α is defined by:

μk⁢(α)=E⁢[(X-α)k]

Therefore, μ1(0)=E[X]=μ=μ1′ (=μ1)
  and        μ2⁢(μ)=E⁢[(X-α)2]=σ2=μ2

These μk′ are the raw moments (i.e. about zero) and μk are the centred moments (i.e. about the mean).

The coefficients of skewness for a random variable is given by γ1 = μ3σ3.
If the distribution of a random variable is symmetric, then γ1 = 0.

3.8 Median and Mode for a random variable

An alternative to the mean for random variable X is the median:

P(X<median)≤0.5
P(X≤median)≥0.5

If X is continuous, the median, lower and upper quartiles are defined respectively by:
 
∫-∞medianfX⁢(x)⁢𝑑x=0.5    ∫-∞L⁢QfX⁢(x)⁢𝑑x=0.25     ∫-∞U⁢QfX⁢(x)⁢𝑑x=0.75

The mode is often easier to find because we use differentiation, The mode is the maximum of fX(x). So, in many cases,

fX′⁢(mode)=0 with fX′′⁢(mode)<0.

This falls down in cases of bimodality and discontinuous distributions.

Example 16
(a) Let X be a random variable with pdf: f(x)=(1/263)(153+420x-300x2) (if 0≤x≤1), 0 (otherwise).

d⁢fX⁢(x)d⁢x = 420/263-600/263⁢x,
d⁢fX⁢(Mode)d⁢x = 0
⟹Mode = 420/600=0.7.

And the second derivative is negative. It is also worth checking the values at x=0 and x=1.

(b) Let X be a random variable with pdf: f(x)=4-2x (if 1≤x≤2), 0 (otherwise). We have that

0.5 = ∫1m4-2⁢x⁢d⁢x,
⟹0 = -m2+4⁢m-3.5
⟹m = 2-2/2.

3.9 Functions of random variables (continuous)

If we have a random variable X and a function (with unique inverse) defined for all values of X, u(.), then we can consider the properties of Y=u⁢(X) (we have already considered a transformation’s impacts on expectation earlier).

FY⁢(y) = P(Y≤y) is what we are interested in and we can recover fY(y) by differentiation of FY(y).

We know FX(x), and y=u(x) has a unique inverse:

x=w(y)=u-1(y).     (*)

If u(x) is an increasing function, then

FY⁢(y) = P(Y<y)=P(u(X)<y)
= P(X<w(y))=FX(w(y)),

and, hence,

fY⁢(y) = d⁢FX⁢(w⁢(y))d⁢y
= d⁢FX⁢(z)d⁢z⁢d⁢w⁢(y)d⁢y   [using chain rule]
= fX⁢(w⁢(y))⁢d⁢w⁢(y)d⁢y.

We know FX⁢(x) and y=u⁢(x) has a unique inverse as given in (*). If u⁢(x) is a decreasing function, then

FY⁢(y) = P(u(x)<y)=P(X>w(y))
= 1-FX⁢(w⁢(y)),

and, hence,

fY⁢(y) = d⁢(1-FX⁢(w⁢(y)))d⁢y
= -fX⁢(w⁢(y))⁢d⁢w⁢(y)d⁢y.

Both cases can be summed up in one result:

fY⁢(y)=fX⁢(w⁢(y))⁢|d⁢(w⁢(y))d⁢y|

because the derivative of a increasing function will be positive and the derivative of a decreasing function will be negative.

Example 17
Let X be a random variable with pdf: f(x)=4-2x (if 1≤x≤2), 0 (otherwise). Consider the random variable Y=X. What is the pdf for Y?

y = u⁢(x)=x.
x = w⁢(y)=y2.

Using the formula, we get: f(y) =8y-4y3 (if 1≤y≤2), 0 (otherwise).

Maybe draw pdf and point out mode and approx median.

4 Discrete Distributions (CT3 Unit 4)

4.1 Uniform

Equal probability of each outcome in the sample space.

PF and CDF graphs

4.1.1 Probability Function

If we have k possible outcomes, we have
P(X=x)=1k,x=1,2,…,k.

4.1.2 Moments

Example 18
\hdashlineμ=E⁢[X]=(1+2+…+k)k=(k⁢(k+1)/2)k=(k+1)2, μ2′=E⁢[X2]=(12+22+…+k2)k=(k+1)⁢(2⁢k+1)6, σ2=Var⁢(X)=(k2-1)12. \hdashline

4.2 Bernoulli

X∼ Bernoulli(p),

Outcome of one trial with binary outcome, i.e. 𝒮={0,1}

4.2.1 Probability Function

P(X=1)=p,    P(X=0)=1-p.

4.2.2 Moments

E⁢[X]=p.

Example 19
\hdashlineWhat is Var⁢(X)? Var⁢(X)=E⁢(X2)-E⁢(X)2 E⁢(X)2=p2 E⁢(X2)=(02)×(1-p)+(12)×(p)=p Therefore, Var⁢(X)=p-p2=p⁢(1-p) Note that, the closer that p is to 0.5, the more variability there is. \hdashline

4.3 Binomial

X∼ Bin(n,p),

Number of successes in n Bernoulli trials (n independent Bernoulli trials with fixed p).

4.3.1 Probability Function

P(X=x)=(nx)px(1-p)n-x

(nx) takes in order of successes into consideration. Note that (nx)=Cxn=Cxn=n!x!⁢(n-x)! (counting up the combinations).

We could have:
00101, x=2,
11000, x=2,     Same # of successes, but different order/combination
01010, x=2.

4.3.2 Moments

μ=E⁢[X]=n⁢p

σ2=E⁢[(X-μ)2]=n⁢p⁢(1-p)

Example 20
\hdashlineFrom the population of accountants based in the UK working for private firms, it is believed that 80% of them got a pay-rise in real terms in the last financial year. If we assume that pay rises are independent across accountants and we can take a random sample of 50 UK accountants working in private firms, what is the expected value of accountants with pay rises in the last year and what is the standard deviation? Let X be the number of accountants with pay rises out of our random sample of 50. We might say that X∼Bin⁢(50,0.8), then E⁢(X) = n⁢p=40, Var⁢(X) = n⁢p⁢(1-p)=8, Std Dev⁢(X) = 8=2.8⁢ to 1 d.p.. \hdashline

4.4 Geometric

X∼ Geo(p),

Number of Bernoulli trials until the first success occurs.

4.4.1 Probability Function

P(X=x)=p(1-p)x-1

4.4.2 Moments

μ=1p
σ2=(1-p)p2

Example 21
\hdashlineIf we were to pick accountants (as defined in the previous example) at random, how many would we expect to have to consider until we found one who had not had a pay rise? Let A be the number of accountants we need to consider to find the first accountant who has not had a pay rise in real terms, then A∼Geo⁢(0.2) and E⁢(A) = 1/0.2=5, Var⁢(A) = 0.8/0.04=20. \hdashline

Sometimes a Geometric random variable is defined in an alternative way: consider Y=X-1, Y∼ Geo(p) and thus,

P(Y=y) = p⁢(1-p)y

Now, μ=1p-1 and σ2=(1-p)p2

Either including the success trial or not

4.5 Poisson

X∼ Po(λ)

Number of independent events in a specified time interval.

This distribution models the number of events in a specified time interval, when events occur one after another in a well-defined manner. This manner presumes that the events occur, singularly, at a constant rate and that the number of events that occur in two non-overlapping time intervals are independent.

4.5.1 Probability Function

P(X=x)=λx⁢e-λx!,x=0,1,2,…,∞;λ> 0,

P(X=x)=λxP(X=x-1).

4.5.2 Moments

μ=E⁢[X]=λ=Var⁢(X)=σ2

Example 22
\hdashlineUse top board so that R can be projected! Assume that the number of insurance claims per hour (X, say) for some small insurance company is distributed as a Poisson with rate 1. The company is worried that they cannot cope with more than 4 claims per hour. What is the probability of getting more than 4 claims in an hour? By hand, we could work out P(X>4)=1-P(X=0)-⋯-P(X=4). We can easily calculate this using R: 1-ppois(4,1): 0.0037 to 2 s.f.. \hdashline

The Poisson distribution provides an approximation to the binomial distribution when n is large and p is small. Typically, we will want n> 100 and p<120. Given X∼ Bin(n,p) with large n and small p, then X   ⋅ ∼   ⋅ Po(n⁢p) can be used as a very good approximation.

Example 23
\hdashlineLet X∼B⁢i⁢n⁢(1000,0.01), then X ≈ P ⁢ o ⁢ ( 10 ) . Show tables. \hdashline

When events are described as occurring “as a Poisson process with rate lambda” or “randomly at a rate of lambda units per unit time”, then the number of events which occur in a time period of length t follows the Poisson distribution with parameter λ⁢t.

Example 24
\hdashlineThe rate of component failures at a factory is thought to be 0.02 per hour. If we accept that failures are happening independently and there are no “peak times”, what is the probability of two failures in any 24 hour period? Let X be the number of failures in a 24 hour period, then X∼P⁢o⁢(24×0.02)=P⁢o⁢(0.48). P(X=2)=0.482⁢exp⁡(-0.48)2!=0.07 (to 2 d.p.) The mean number of failures in a 24 hour period is 0.48. \hdashline

5 Continuous Distributions (CT3 Unit 4)

5.1 Uniform

X∼ Uniform(a,b)

Equal probability density across an interval.

5.1.1 Probability density function

fX⁢(x)=1b-a   for x∈(a,b).

Graph of density

5.1.2 Moments

E⁢[X]=(a+b)/2   and   Var⁢(X)=(b-a)2/12.

Example 25
\hdashline Var⁢(X) = E⁢(X2)-E⁢(X)2, E⁢(X)2 = (a+b)24, E⁢(X2) = ∫abx2b-a⁢𝑑x = 1b-a⁢[x3/3]ab=13⁢b3-a3b-a, Var⁢(X) = 112⁢(b-a)⁢(4⁢b3-4⁢a3-3⁢a2⁢b-6⁢a⁢b2-3⁢b3+3⁢a3+6⁢a2⁢b+3⁢a⁢b2) = 112⁢(b-a)⁢(b3-a3+3⁢a2⁢b-3⁢a⁢b2)=(b-a)312⁢(b-a). \hdashline

5.2 Beta

x∼Be⁢(α,β)

f⁢(x)∝xα-1⁢(1-x)β-1=Γ⁢(α+β)Γ⁢(α)⁢Γ⁢(β)⁢xα-1⁢(1-x)β-1  x∈[0,1]

A flexible distribution over an interval.

Graph of density

5.3 Gamma

X∼ Ga(α,λ) with α>0 and λ>0.

A family of distributions that includes two special cases.
We define the gamma function Γ⁢(α) as:

Γ⁢(α)=∫0∞yα-1⁢e-y⁢𝑑y

Γ⁢(1)=1,Γ⁢(α)=(α-1)!    when α∈ℕ.

5.3.1 Probability density function

fX⁢(x)=λα⁢xα-1⁢e-λ⁢xΓ⁢(α)   for x> 0.

5.3.2 Moments

E⁢[X]=αλ and Var⁢(X)=αλ2

5.4 Gamma special case - Exponential

Gamma with α = 1, X∼ Exp(λ) [ ∼ Gamma(1, λ)].

5.4.1 Probability density function

fX⁢(x) = λ⁢e-λ⁢x,x>0.

5.4.2 Moments

E⁢(X)=1λ,Var⁢(X)=1λ2.

5.4.3 Cumulative distribution function

FX⁢(x)=∫0xλ⁢eλ⁢t
         =1-e-λ⁢x.

The exponential distribution is used as a simple model of lifetimes. It also gives the distribution of waiting times between events regenerate by a Poisson process.

Diagram explaining waiting times and relation to Poisson

Example 26
\hdashlineRecall the insurance company from example 22. They had an hourly rate of 1 claim. They were worried about getting more than four claims in one hour, but, on reflection, they are actually worried about getting a claim less than five minutes after receiving the previous claim. Let Y be the number of minutes between claims. The Poisson rate per minute is 1/60; therefore, Y∼E⁢x⁢p⁢(1/60). E⁢(Y)=60 minutes and Var⁢(Y)=3600⁢ minutes2 (which corresponds to a standard deviation of 60 minutes). P(Y<5)=∫05exp⁡(-x/60)60dx=0.08 (to 2 d.p. using pexp(5,1/60). \hdashline

5.5 Gamma special case - χ2 -distribution

Gamma with α=ν2,  where ν is a positive integer and λ=12, then,

X∼χν2[∼Gamma⁢(ν2,12)]

5.5.1 Moments

E⁢(X)=ν,Var⁢(X)=2⁢ν.

This distribution is important because it is widely used in Statistics.

Note: a χ2 variable with ν=2 is an exponential with mean 2.

5.6 Normal Distribution (or Gaussian distribution)

X∼ N(μ,σ2)

This distribution with its symmetrical “bell-shaped” density curve is of fundamental importance in both statistical theory and practice. Why?
(1) It often occurs in nature.
(2) It provides good approximations to other distributions - in particular it is
     a good approximation for the Binomial distribution.
(3) It provides a distribution widely used in Statistics.
(4) When we have large data sets, we often see normal behaviour.

5.6.1 Probability density function

fX⁢(x)=1σ⁢2⁢π⁢exp⁡{-(x-μ)22⁢σ2},x∈ℝ.

Its mean and variance are E⁢(X)=μ⁢and⁢Var⁢(X)=σ2,

If μ=0⁢ and ⁢σ2=1, we have the standard normal distribution, Z∼N⁢(0,1), for which we use the following notation:

fZ⁢(z)=ϕ⁢(Z),FZ⁢(z)=Φ⁢(Z).

(Note that it is impossible to write out an analytic expression for FX⁢(x).)

A linear function of a normal variable X is also normally distributed:

If ⁢Y = a⁢X+b,
then ⁢Y ∼ N⁢(a⁢μ+b,a2⁢σ2).

Example 27
\hdashlineLet X∼N⁢(4,4). What are P(X<3), P(X≥6) and the 95th percentile of X’s distribution? We first standardise X: Z=(X-4)/4=X/2-2. Using properties of the normal distribution, Z∼N⁢(0,1). P(X<3)=P(Z<-0.5)=Φ(-0.5)=1-Φ(0.5)=1-0.6915=0.31. P(X≥6)=P(Z≥1)=1-Φ(1)=1-0.8413=0.16. From tables, P(Z<1.6449)=0.95=P(X<1.6449×2+4), which implies that the 95th percentile of X is 7.29 to 2 d.p.. \hdashline

5.7 Lognormal Distribution

The lognormal distribution is the distribution of a log-transformed normal random variable.

This distribution is important because it is used to model positive random variables. Many of which we see in finance.

If X represents some positive random variable and Y=log⁢(X) with Y∼N(μ,σ2), then X∼L⁢N⁢(μ,σ2).

5.7.1 Probability density function

(See section 3.9.)

fX⁢(x)=1x⁢σ⁢2⁢π⁢exp⁡{-(log⁡(x)-μ)22⁢σ2}   for x>0.

Note that E⁢(X)≠μ,Var⁢(X)≠σ2.

5.8 Student’s t-distribution

X∼tν

Many sample statistics will have this distribution, and ν is the degrees of freedom parameter that has a large bearing on the kurtosis of the distribution.

Graph showing change in kurtosis

5.9 Random Number Generation

A basic simulation method starts with the generation of a uniformly distributed random variable on the interval (0, 1), call this U.

Suppose we want to generate a random value from the distribution of X that has FX⁢(x).

For our random number u, we set x=FX-1⁢(u), and this is a random draw from the distribution of X.

Example 28
\hdashline X∼Exp⁢(λ). FX⁢(x) = 1-e(-λ⁢x) FX⁢(x) = u=1-e(-λ⁢x) ⟹ e(-λ⁢x)=1-u ⟹ -λ⁢x=log⁢(1-u) ⟹ x=-1λ⁢log⁢(1-u). \hdashline

Sampling from the Exponential in this way is very important in Stochastic processes and simulation of Markov processes

6 Generating Functions (CT3 Unit 5)

6.1 Probability generating functions - Discrete

Let X be a counting variable which take values 0,1,2,3,… (i.e., x∈ℕ∪{0}) with probabilities p0,p1,p2,p3,… respectively. We define the probability generating function (PGF) as

GX⁢(t) = E⁢[tX]
= p0+p1⁢t+p2⁢t2+…

Thus, pk equals the coefficient of tk in GX(t). It is easy to see that GX⁢(1)=1 and GX⁢(0) = P(X=0). GX⁢(t) exists at least for |t|≤1. This gives us an alternative mechanism for describing the distribution of a discrete random variable.

Also, if X and Y have the same probability generating function, then they have the same distribution.

6.2 Evaluating moments using PGFs

The PGF, GX⁢(t), can be used relatively easily to find low-order moments.

If we differentiate GX⁢(t) with respect to t and set t=1, we end up with E⁢[X]:

E⁢[X]=d⁢GX⁢(t)d⁢t|t=1.

Further differentiation yields higher order moments. Recall Var⁢(X)=E⁢[X2]-{E⁢[X]}2, and, using PGFs, we have

E⁢[X2]=d2⁢GX⁢(t)d⁢t2|t=1+d⁢GX⁢(t)d⁢t|t=1.

Example 29
\hdashlineShow that the PGF for a uniform distribution over k outcomes, 1,…,k is GX⁢(t)=tk⁢(1-tk)(1-t)⁢ for ⁢t≠1. GX⁢(t) = E⁢(tX)=1k⁢(t+t2+⋯+tk) = tk⁢(1-tk)(1-t) using the fact (sum of a geometric series) that ∑k=0n-1a⁢xk=a⁢(1-xk)(1-x)⁢ for ⁢x≠1. \hdashline

Example 30
\hdashlineFind the PGF of X∼ Po(λ). P(X=x)=λx⁢e-λx!,x=0,1,2,3,… GX⁢(t) = e-λ⁢∑x=0∞(λ⁢t)xx! = e-λ⁢eλ⁢t = eλ⁢(t-1) Now, find the mean and variance of X∼ Po(λ). E⁢[X]=d⁢GX⁢(t)d⁢t|t=1=d⁢eλ⁢(t-1)d⁢t|t=1=d⁢e-λ⁢eλ⁢td⁢t|t=1=λ⁢e-λ⁢eλ⁢t|t=1 =λ⁢e-λ⁢eλ=λ d2⁢GX⁢(t)d⁢t2|t=1=λ⁢e-λ⁢d⁢eλ⁢td⁢t|t=1=λ2⁢e-λ⁢eλ⁢t|t=1 =λ2 Therefore, we can put all these into the variance equation, Var(X) = E[X^2] - {E[X]}^2 = λ^2 + λ- λ^2 = λ. \hdashline

6.3 Moment Generating Functions (Discrete and Continuous)

The moment generating function (MGF), MX⁢(t), of a random variable X is given by:

MX⁢(t)=E⁢[exp⁡(t⁢X)] ∀t for which this expectation exists.

By expanding the exponential term, we get                [ex=∑n=0∞xnn!]

MX⁢(t)=1+t⁢E⁢[X]+t22!⁢E⁢[X2]+t33!⁢E⁢[X3]+…,

and, from this, it can be seen that the kt⁢h raw moment is the coefficient of tkk!.

Another method to find the kt⁢h raw moment is to differentiate MX⁢(t)⁢k times and set t=0.

If an MGF can be found, then there is a unique distribution associated with it. So, if two random variables have the same MGF, then they have the same distribution. For a counting variable which has PGF GX⁢(t)[=E⁢[tX]], then its MGF can be found by substituting the et for t in GX⁢(t):

MX⁢(t)=GX⁢(et).

Example 31
\hdashlineX∼ Po(λ), MX⁢(t)=exp⁡{λ⁢(et-1)}=exp⁡{-λ}⁢exp⁡{λ⁢et}, d⁢MX⁢(t)d⁢t|t=0=e-λ⁢d⁢exp⁡{λ⁢et}d⁢t|t=0 [ Letting y=et,d⁢exp⁡{λ⁢et}d⁢t=d⁢exp⁡{λ⁢et}d⁢yd⁢yd⁢t=λexp{λet}et] Set t=0,⟹e-λλeλ=λ \hdashline

Example 32
\hdashlineX∼N(μ,σ2), M(t)X=exp{μt+12σ2t2} [expand using ex=∑n=0∞xnn!] =1+(μ⁢t+12⁢σ2⁢t2)+12⁢(μ⁢t+12⁢σ2⁢t2)2+… Reading off the coefficient of t we find E⁢[X]=μ. Reading off the coefficient of t22!, we find E⁢[X2]=σ2+μ2. Var⁢(X)=E⁢[X2]-{E⁢[X]}2=σ2. \hdashline

7 Joint Distribution (CT3 Unit 6)

Defining several random variables on a sample space gives rise to a multivariate distribution. If you have two random variables, then you have a bivariate distribution.

Example 33
\hdashlineBivariate - We have random variables X and Y whose joint probability distribution is defined by the following table: x 1 2 3 1 0.10 0.10 0.05 y 2 0.15 0.10 0.05 3 0.20 0.05 0.00 4 0.15 0.05 0.00 These probabilities add up to 1. For example, from the table, we can see that P(X=3,Y=1)=0.05. \hdashline

7.1 Notation and properties

The function fX,Y(x,y) = P(X=x,Y=y), defined for all possible values of x and y, is the joint probability function.

To have a joint probability function for two (discrete) random variables, we require

fX,Y⁢(x,y)≥0   (every probability is positive),
∑x∑yfX,Y⁢(x,y)=1   (all probabilities add up to 1).

In the case of a pair of continuous variables, we have a function fX,Y(x,y) defined over the x,y - plane, called the joint probability density function.

The probability of X,Y taking values in some region is given by:

P(x1<X<x2,y1<Y<y2)=∫y1y2∫x1x2f(x,y)dxdy

We are integrating the area under a surface defined by z=f⁢(x,y) so we need to look at double integration.

The joint distribution function is defined by

F(x,y)=P(X<x,Y<y),

and it is related to the density function through

∂2⁡FX,Y⁢(x,y)∂⁡x⁢∂⁡y=fX,Y⁢(x,y).

To qualify as a joint probability density function, we must have that

fX,Y⁢(x,y)≥0,∀x,y,
∫-∞∞∫-∞∞fX,Y⁢(x,y)⁢𝑑x⁢𝑑y=1.

Example 34
\hdashlineWe have f_X,Y(x,y) = { axy 0≤x≤2,1≤y ≤2, 0 otherwise. Find a such that fX,Y⁢(x,y) is a pdf. ∫12∫02a⁢x⁢y⁢𝑑x⁢𝑑y = 1=∫12[a⁢x2⁢y/2]x=0x=2⁢𝑑y = ∫122⁢a⁢y⁢𝑑y=[a⁢y2]12 = 4⁢a-a=3⁢a=1⟹a=1/3. Of course, for this choice of a, f⁢(x,y)≥0⁢∀x,y. \hdashline

7.2 Marginal Probability (Density) Functions

The marginal probability function for a discrete random variable X is defined as

fX⁢(x)=∑yfX,Y⁢(x,y).

Example 35
\hdashlineP(X=3)=0.1 (from earlier table, add up column for X=3) P(Y=1)=0.25 \hdashline

In the continuous case, fX(x) is obtained by integrating over the possible values of y:

fX⁢(x)=∫-∞∞fX,Y⁢(x,y)⁢𝑑y.

Example 36
\hdashlineFrom example 35, we have f_X,Y(x,y) = { xy 3 0≤x≤2,1≤y ≤2, 0 otherwise. What are the marginal densities for X and Y? f_X(x) = ∫_1^2 xy 3 dy = 1 6 [xy^2]_1^2 = x/2. f_Y(y) = ∫_0^2 xy 3 dx = 2y/3. Perhaps sketch these to show they are pdfs. \hdashline

7.3 Conditional Probability (Density) Function

The distribution of X for a particular value of Y is called the conditional distribution of X given Y=y.

For a discrete variable,

PX|Y=y(x|y)=P(X=x|Y=y)=PX,Y⁢(x,y)PY⁢(y).

Example 37
\hdashlineFrom the earlier table: P(X=2|Y=2)=P(X=2,Y=2)P(Y=2)=0.10.3=13 P(Y=4|X=1)=0.150.6=14 P(Y=2|X=2)=0.10.3=13 P(Y=3|X=3)=0 P(X=3|Y=3)=0 P(X=2|Y=3)=0.050.25=15  (*) P(Y=3|X=2)=0.050.3=16 \hdashline

Example 38
\hdashlineBayes’s theorem: P(X=2|Y=3)=P(Y=3|X=2)P(X=2)P(Y=3) =16⁢3/101/4=1260=15, which is the same as (*). \hdashline

For continuous variables, fX|Y=y⁢(x|y) is the conditional density, and we get the conditional probabilities:

P(x1<X<x2|Y=y) = ∫x1x2fX|Y=y⁢(x|y)⁢𝑑x
= ∫x1x2fX,Y⁢(x,y)fY⁢(y)⁢𝑑x.

Example 39
\hdashlineFrom example 35, we have f_X,Y(x,y) = { xy 3 0≤x≤2,1≤y ≤2, 0 otherwise. What is P(X<1|Y=2)? f_X—Y=2(x—y=2)= f X,Y (x,2) f Y (2) = 2x/3 f Y (2) . From example 37, we have fY⁢(y)=2⁢y/3; therefore, fY⁢(2)=4/3. P(X¡1—Y=2) = ∫_0^1 x/2 dx = 1/4. \hdashline

7.4 Independence of Random Variables

Consider a pair of random variables (X,Y) and suppose that Y does not actually depend on X at all. It follows that the conditional distribution of Y|X, f⁢(y|x), is simply the marginal distribution of Y, fY⁢(y). So,

fY⁢(y) = f⁢(y|x)=fX,Y⁢(x,y)fX⁢(x)
⟹ fX,Y⁢(x,y)=fX⁢(x)⁢fY⁢(y).

X and Y are independent if, and only if, the joint probability density function for X and Y is the product of the two marginals,

fX,Y⁢(x,y)=fX⁢(x)⁢fY⁢(y).

Example 40
\hdashline(a) From example 35, we have f_X,Y(x,y) = { xy 3 0≤x≤2,1≤y ≤2, 0 otherwise. From example 37, we have fX⁢(x)=x/2 and fY⁢(y)=2⁢y/3. Therefore, fX,Y⁢(x,y)=fX⁢(x)⁢fY⁢(y) and X and Y are independent. (b) Consider the joint density for X and Y: f_X,Y(x,y) = { x/5 + y/5 0≤x≤2,1≤y ≤2, 0 otherwise. It is easy to show that fX⁢(x)=x/5+3/10 and fY⁢(y)=2⁢(y+1)/5. Therefore, X and Y are not independent. \hdashline

7.5 Expectation of Functions of two variables

The basic rule for expectation is: ∑valuesvalue × probability of seeing that value.

For discrete variables, E⁢[g⁢(x,y)]=∑x∑yg⁢(x,y)⁢PX,Y⁢(x,y),

and, for continuous variables, E⁢[g⁢(x,y)]=∫x∫yg⁢(x,y)⁢fX,Y⁢(x,y)⁢𝑑x⁢𝑑y. Let ⁢g⁢(X,Y)=X+Y⁢ then E⁢[X+Y]=E⁢[X]+E⁢[Y].
Let ⁢g⁢(X,Y)=a⁢g1⁢(X)+b⁢g2⁢(Y)⁢ then E⁢[g⁢(X,Y)]=a⁢E⁢[g1⁢(X)]+b⁢E⁢[g2⁢(X)]
(by the linearity of expectation)

Consider a product of two functions: h⁢(X,Y)=h1⁢(X)⁢h2⁢(Y). In general,

E⁢[h⁢(X,Y)]≠E⁢[h1⁢(X)]⁢E⁢[h2⁢(Y)],

but, if X and Y are independent, we can write

E⁢[h⁢(X,Y)]=E⁢[h1⁢(X)]⁢E⁢[h2⁢(Y)].

Example 41
\hdashlineFrom example 35, we have f_X,Y(x,y) = { xy 3 0≤x≤2,1≤y ≤2, 0 otherwise, and, from example 37, we have fX⁢(x)=x/2 and fY⁢(y)=2⁢y/3. What is E⁢(X⁢Y)? E(XY) = ∫_0^2∫_1^2 x 2 y 2 3 dydx = ∫_0^2(7/9)x^2dx = 56/27. Because X and Y are independent, we can also use E⁢(X⁢Y)=E⁢(X)⁢E⁢(Y). We can easily find that E⁢(X)=4/3 and E⁢(Y)=14/9. Multiplying these together gives 56/27. \hdashline

7.6 Covariance and Correlation Coefficient

The covariance between X and Y is defined as:

Cov⁢(X,Y) = E⁢[(X-E⁢[X])⁢(Y-E⁢[Y])]
= E⁢[X⁢Y]-E⁢[X]⁢E⁢[Y].
Note that Cov⁢(X,X) = E⁢[(X-E⁢[X])⁢(X-E⁢[X])]
= E⁢[(X-E⁢[X])2]
= Var⁢(X).

ρX,Y is the correlation coefficient such that ρX,Y=Cov⁢(X,Y)(Var⁢(X)⁢Var⁢(Y)).

This is a quantity between -1 and 1. The closer |ρX,Y| is to 1 the stronger the linear relationship. If ρX,Y = 0, we say that X and Y are uncorrelated, and they have no linear relationship.

If X and Y are independent, then,

ρX,Y=0.

If ρX,Y = 0, however, X and Y may still be dependent.

Slides about correlation strength

Example 42
\hdashlineConsider the joint density for X and Y: f_X,Y(x,y) = { x/5 + y/5 0≤x≤2,1≤y ≤2, 0 otherwise. It is easy to show that fX⁢(x)=x/5+3/10 and fY⁢(y)=2⁢(y+1)/5. From the marginals, we need E⁢(X)=17/15 and E⁢(Y)=23/15. We can also get E⁢(X⁢Y)=26/15. Therefore, Cov⁢(X,Y)=26/15-(17×23)/(15×15)=-0.004 to 3 decimal places; hence, we know that there is negative correlation between X and Y. \hdashline

Some Additional Facts about Covariances

Var⁢(X+Y)=Var⁢(X)+Var⁢(Y)+2⁢Cov⁢(X,Y)

Cov⁢(a⁢X+b⁢Y,c⁢S+d⁢T)=a⁢c⁢Cov⁢(X,S)+a⁢d⁢Cov⁢(X,T)+b⁢c⁢Cov⁢(Y,S)+b⁢d⁢Cov⁢(Y,T)

Now, if a=b=c=d=1 and X=S,Y=T, then Cov⁢(X+Y,X+Y)=Var⁢(X+Y).

Also, note that Cov⁢(X,Y)=Cov⁢(Y,X).

7.7 Distributions of linear combinations of r.v.s via generating functions

7.7.1 PGFs

Suppose that we have X and Y independent counting variables with PGFs G(t)X and G(t)Y respectively. Let

S=c1⁢X+c2⁢Y

Then,

GS⁢(t) = E⁢[t(c1⁢X+c2⁢Y)]
= E⁢[tc1⁢X⁢tc2⁢Y]=E⁢[tc1⁢X]⁢E⁢[tc2⁢Y]
= GX⁢(tc1)⁢GY⁢(tc2)

In the simple case of Z=X+Y,

GZ⁢(t)=GX⁢(t)⁢GY⁢(t).

Example 43
\hdashlineX∼ Po(λ) and Y∼ Po(γ), with X and Y independent. X has PGF, GX(t)=exp{λ(t - 1)} and Y has PGF, GY(t)=exp{γ(t - 1)}. So, Z=X+Y has PGF, GZ⁢(t) = exp⁡{λ⁢(t-1)}⁢exp⁡{γ⁢(t-1)} = exp⁡{(λ+γ)⁢(t-1)}. We get Z∼ Po(λ+γ) by uniqueness of PGFs. \hdashline

7.7.2 Moment generating functions

Suppose X and Y are independent random variables with MGFs, MX⁢(t) and MY⁢(t). Let

S=c1⁢X+c2⁢Y,

then,

MS⁢(t) = E⁢[e(c1⁢X+c2⁢Y)⁢t]
= E⁢[ec1⁢X⁢t⁢ec2⁢Y⁢t]
= E⁢[ec1⁢X⁢t]⁢E⁢[ec2⁢Y⁢t]
= MX⁢(c1⁢t)⁢MY⁢(c2⁢t).

Example 44
\hdashlineX∼N(μX,σX2) and Y∼N(μY,σY2), with X and Y independent. MX⁢(t)=exp⁡(μX⁢t+12⁢σX2⁢t2) Z=X+Y has MGF, MZ⁢(t) = exp⁡(μX⁢t+12⁢σX2⁢t2)⁢exp⁡(μY⁢t+12⁢σY2⁢t2) = exp⁡{(μX+μY)⁢t+12⁢(σX2+σY2)⁢t2}. Therefore, Z∼N(μX+μY,σX2+σY2) through the uniqueness of MGFs. \hdashline

8 The Central Limit Theorem (CT3 Unit 7)

If X1,X2,…⁢Xn is a sequence of independent and identically distributed (iid) random variables with mean μ and variance σ2 (both finite), then the distribution of

X¯-μσ/n

approaches the standard normal distribution, N⁢(0,1), as n→∞. Therefore, both X¯-μσ/n and (∑Xi)-n⁢μn⁢σ2, are approximately distributed as N⁢(0,1) for “large” n.

Alternatively, the unstandardised form can be used:

X¯   ⋅ ∼   ⋅ N⁢(μ,σ2n)   and   ∑i=1nXi   ⋅ ∼   ⋅ N⁢(n⁢μ,n⁢σ2),

Note that by “large” n, we mean roughly over 30.

Demonstration in R?

8.1 Normal Approximations

When summing a number of independent random variables, we often use the CLT as a basis for an approximation

Example 45
\hdashlineLet Xi be i.i.d. Bernoulli random variables such that P(Xi=1) = θ, P(Xi=0) = 1-θ. Consider a sequence X1,X2,…,Xn of such random variables, and set X=∑i=1nXi,X ∼ Bin⁢(n,θ),also note that   Xn=X¯ By the Central Limit Theorem, for large n, X¯   ⋅ ∼   ⋅ N⁢(μ,σ2n)   or  ∑i=1nXi   ⋅ ∼   ⋅ N⁢(n⁢μ,n⁢σ2). For the Bernoulli distribution, μ = E⁢[Xi]=θ, σ2 = Var⁢(Xi)=θ⁢(1-θ). So, if X∼ Bin(n,θ), then we can say, X   ⋅ ∼   ⋅ N⁢(n⁢θ,n⁢θ⁢(1-θ)). Let Y∼N⁢(n⁢θ,n⁢θ⁢(1-θ)). Therefore, X   ⋅ ∼   ⋅ Y. Example: P(X≤5)≈P(Y<5.5). \hdashline

Example 46
\hdashlineConsider a sequence U1,U2,…,Un of i.i.d. random variables where Ui∼Uniform⁢(0,1)⁢∀i and n is large. What is the distribution of T=π⁢∑i=1nUi? We know that E⁢(Ui)=1/2 and Var⁢(Ui)=1/12. Therefore, using the central limit theorem, we have ∑i=1nUi   ⋅ ∼   ⋅ N⁢(n/2,n/12), π⁢∑i=1nUi   ⋅ ∼   ⋅ N⁢(π⁢n/2,π2⁢n/12). \hdashline

End of 1st third of course

9 Sampling & Inference (CT3 Unit 8)

When a sample is taken from a population, the sample information can be used to infer certain things about the population. A random sample is made up of i.i.d. random variables, Xi. We use the notation X = {X1,X2,…,Xn} for a random sample. An observed sample is denoted by x = {x1,x2,…,xn}. The population density is denoted by f(x;θ) where θ represents any distribution parameters.

A statistic is a function of X alone and does not involve any component of θ.

Example 47
\hdashlineThus, X¯=∑i=1nXin and s2 = 1n-1⁢∑i=1n(Xi-X¯)2 are statistics whereas 1n⁢∑i=1n(Xi-μ)2 is not a statistic unless μ is known. \hdashline

A statistic is denoted generally by g(X), and, because it is a function of something random, it is random itself.

9.1 Moments of the sample mean and variance

Suppose that i.i.d. random variables Xi have mean μ and variance σ2. Now, the sample mean is

X¯ = ∑i=1nXin.
E⁢(∑i=1nXi) = ∑i=1nE⁢[Xi]=∑i=1nμ=n⁢μ,
Var⁢(∑i=1nXi) = ∑i=1nVar⁢(Xi)=n⁢σ2.

So,

E⁢[X¯]=E⁢[∑Xi]n=μ,
Var⁢(X¯)=Var⁢(∑Xi)n2=σ2n,

and

Std. Dev.⁢(X¯)=Var⁢(X¯)=σn,

which is the standard error of the mean.

The sample variance is S2=1n-1⁢∑(Xi-X¯)2.

So we have

E⁢(S2) = 1n-1⁢∑E⁢[(Xi-X¯)2],

and,

E⁢[(Xi-X¯)2] = E⁢{[(Xi-μ)-(X¯-μ)]2}
= E⁢[(Xi-μ)2]-2⁢E⁢[(Xi-μ)⁢(X¯-μ)]+E⁢[(X¯-μ)2].

We can rewrite this expression using:

E⁢[(Xi-μ)2] = σ2,
E⁢[(X¯-μ)2] = σ2n,
E⁢[(Xi-μ)⁢(X¯-μ)] = σ2n.

Therefore,

E⁢(S2) = 1n-1⁢∑(σ2-σ2n)
= σ2.
Do the extended version on the board and mention issues with deriving 𝑉𝑎𝑟⁢(S2).

9.2 Sampling distributions when data are normal

The Central Limit Theorem provides a distribution for X¯ without any assumptions about the distribution of the Xi if n is large enough.

Recall, for large n,

X¯   ⋅ ∼   ⋅ N⁢(μ,σ2n).

If Xi are i.i.d. normal, then

X¯∼N⁢(μ,σ2n).
We can rearrange this to get the “Z result”.

The sampling distribution for S2 when sampling from N(μ,σ2) is

(n-1)σ2⁢S2∼χn-12.

[
Informal sketch of Proof — not examinable!
Firstly we note that the moment generating function of a χk2 random variable is MX⁢(t)=(1-2⁢t)-k/2. Using this fact, it is then easy to verify that, if Xi∼χki2,i=1,2,…,M, and independent, then ∑Xi∼χK2 where K=∑ki.

Now we use an inductive argument. Let X¯j and Sj2 denote the sample mean and variance of the first j observations (the order is immaterial). Then we note

(n-1)⁢Sn2=(n-2)⁢Sn-12+(n-1n)⁢(Xn-X¯n-1)2.

Now consider n=2. Defining 0×S12=0, we have that

S22=12⁢(X2-X1)2.

Since the distribution of (X2-X1)/2 is N⁢(0,1) then S22∼χ12. Now proceed by induction, in which we need to check that (j/(j+1))⁢(Xj+1-X¯j)2∼χ12 and is also independent of Sj2.
]

The χn-12 distribution can be derived from ∑i=1nZi2 where Zi∼N⁢(0,1), because ∑i=1nZi2∼χn2 by definition. (In our case we have n-1 degrees of freedom because X¯ is used in place of μ.)

[n-1σ2S2=n-1n-1∑i=1n(Xi-X¯)2σ2,dividing by σ2 gives Var=1.]

Powerpoint slides: Sampling.pptx

We know that S2 is related to the χν2 distribution when sampling from a normal distribution. We know that the mean and variance of a χν2 random variable are ν and 2⁢ν respectively.

E⁢[(n-1)⁢S2σ2] = n-1⟹E⁢[S2]=σ2.
Var⁢((n-1)⁢S2σ2) = 2⁢(n-1)
⟹(n-1)2σ4⁢Var⁢(S2) = 2⁢(n-1)⟹Var⁢(S2)=2⁢σ4(n-1).

9.3 The sampling distribution for X¯ when σ2 is unknown

When σ2 is unknown, we replace σ2 with a suitable estimate, and, if we choose the usual estimate, we will replace the normal sampling distribution with a t-distribution.

Plot comparing t with normal

A t-distribution has “heavier” tails than the normal distribution: it has more probability density at extreme values.

The t-result is similar to the previous result for S2 (the “z” result) with σ2 replaced by S2 and N(0, 1) replaced by tn-1. So, we have

X¯-μS/n∼tn-1

The general tk variable can be defined as tk = N⁢(0,1)χk2/k, where the N(0, 1) part and χk2 part are independent.

From before, X¯-μσ/n∼N⁢(0,1) and (n-1)⁢S2σ2∼χn-12, and, because these are independent, we get

X¯-μσ/n×σ⁢n-1n-1⁢S = (X¯-μ)⁢(n-1)S/n⁢(n-1)
= (X¯-μS/n)∼tn-1.

Now, for a tk variable, we have the mean is 0, and variance is kk-2. (This makes it difficult for small n).

E⁢[X¯-μS/n] = 0⟹E⁢[X¯]=μ.
Var⁢(X¯-μS/n) = n-1n-3.

9.4 The F-result for variance ratios

The F-distribution is defined by U/ν1V/ν2 where U and V are independent χ2 random variables with ν1 and ν2 degrees of freedom respectively.

If independent random samples of size n1 and n2 are taken from normal populations with variance σ12⁢and⁢σ22 respectively, then

S12/σ12S22/σ22∼ℱn1-1,n2-1

or

S22/σ22S12/σ12∼ℱn2-1,n1-1

We have that (n1-1)⁢S12σ12∼χn1-12 and (n2-1)⁢S22σ22∼χn2-12 (both independent).

So,

(n1-1)⁢S12⁢σ22⁢(n2-1)σ12⁢(n2-1)⁢S22⁢(n1-1)=S12/σ12S22/σ22∼ℱn1-1,n2-1[⟹χn1-12χn2-12].

We note that

E⁢(S12/σ12S22/σ22) = E⁢(χn1-12/(n1-1)χn2-12/(n2-1))
= E⁢(χn1-12n1-1)⁢E⁢(n2-1χn2-12)  (since independent)
= (n1-1n1-1)⁢(n2-1n2-3)  (*)
= n2-1n2-3,

and so for reasonably large n2 we have

S12/S22σ12/σ22≈n2-1n2-3≈1.

The statement (*) can be checked using integration by parts. Note also,

  • •

    If X∼Fp,q, then 1/X∼Fq,p

  • •

    If X∼tq, then X2∼F1,q

  • •

    If X∼Fp,q, then (p/q)⁢X/(1+(p/q)⁢X)∼Be⁢(p/1,q/2).

10 Point Estimation (CT3 Unit 9)

10.1 The method of moments

To get estimates of parameters using the method of moments, we set sample moments to be equal to expressions for population moments and solve the resulting equations for the distribution parameters.

10.1.1 One parameter case

The simplest case is where we equate the population mean with the sample mean and solve for the unknown parameter. That is, set

E⁢[X]=1n⁢∑i=1nxi.

Example 48
\hdashlineX∼N(μ,σ2) with known σ2, then using the method of moments, E⁢[X]=μ=set1n⁢∑i=1nxi=x¯. We have our estimator for μ is x¯. \hdashline

Example 49
\hdashlineX∼ Uni(0, θ), E⁢[X]=θ2=setx¯. Our estimator for θ is 2x¯. What if x¯=1.5? X∼ Uni(0, 3) \hdashline

Example 50
\hdashlineX∼ N(0, σ2) E⁢[X]=0 This is not helpful because there is no σ2 in this equation, Var⁢(X)=σ2=setS2 \hdashline

10.1.2 The two parameter case

This involves equating the 1st and 2nd moments of the population with the sample mean and variance respectively.

Example 51
\hdashlineX∼ N(μ,σ2) with both parameters unknown. E⁢[X]=μ=x¯. and, Var⁢(X)=σ2=s2. \hdashline

Example 52
\hdashline X∼ Be(α,β) E⁢[X]=αα+β⁢ and Var⁢(X)=α⁢β(α+β)2⁢(α+β+1). x¯=αα+β ⟹β=αx¯-α s2=α2⁢(1x¯-1)(α-α+αx¯)2⁢(αx¯-1) = (1x¯-1)⁢x¯2αx¯-1 (αx¯-1)=x¯-x¯2s2 α=x¯2-x¯3s2+x¯=x¯⁢(x¯⁢(1-x¯)s2-1) β=αx¯-α⟹β=(1-x¯)⁢(x¯⁢(1-x¯)s2-1) \hdashline

10.2 Maximum Likelihood

The method of moments does not take into account the full distribution: it only accounts for one or two moments and we need infinitely many to describe the distribution.

Powerpoint slides: Sampling.pptx

10.2.1 The one-parameter case

The first step is to write down a likelihood,

l⁢(θ;x¯)∝∏i=1nfXi⁢(xi|θ)

for a random sample x1,x2,x3,…⁢xn from a population with density f⁢(x|θ).

Example 53
\hdashlineX∼ Bin(20,p) We have observed x=5, then l(p;x=5) ∝ P(X=5) ∝ (p)5⁢(1-p)20-5 = (p)5⁢(1-p)15,for p∈(0,1). \hdashline

Might need to explain why taking logs is a good idea and has no effect: show graphs in Sampling.pptx

Differentiating the likelihood (or log-likelihood) and solving for θ after equating with 0, we find the maximum of the likelihood and we call this the maximum likelihood estimator (MLE), θ^. (Of course, we should also check that the 2n⁢d derivative is negative at that value of θ.)

MLEs has the invariance property, which means that, if θ^ is the MLE of θ, then the MLE of g(θ) is g(θ^).

Example 54
\hdashlineWe have a random sample of size n from Xi∼ Exp(λ), with fX⁢(x)=λ⁢e-λ⁢x, for x∈(0,∞) We want to estimate λ given a sample, l⁢(λ;x¯) ∝ ∏i=1nλ⁢e-λ⁢xi = λn⁢e-λ⁢∑xi L⁢(λ;x) = log⁢(l⁢(λ;x¯)) = log⁢(λn)+log⁢(e-λ⁢∑xi)+c = n⁢log⁢λ-λ⁢∑i=1nxi+c. ∂⁡L⁢(λ;x)∂⁡λ = nλ-∑i=1nxi Equate this to zero, ⟹nλ=∑i=1nxi⟹1λ=∑i=1nxin=x¯ ⟹λ^=1x¯ and ∂2⁡L⁢(λ;x¯)∂⁡λ2=-nλ2 For λ^=1x¯, this is negative and we have a max at λ^. So λ^ is a MLE. \hdashline

10.3 Unbiasedness

If we have a random sample X = {X1,…⁢Xn} from a distribution with unknown parameter θ and g(X¯) is an estimator for θ, we want

E[g(X¯)]=θ.   (This is unbiasedness)

If an estimator is biased the bias is measured by E[g(X¯)]-θ. This property is not preserved under non-linear transformations of the estimator and parameter.

Example 55
\hdashlineAn example of a biased estimator is ∑i(Xi-X¯)2n for variance. An unbiased estimator for variance is ∑i(Xi-X¯)2n-1, E⁢[∑i(Xi-X¯)2n-1] = σ2; whereas, E⁢[∑i(Xi-X¯)2n] = σ2⁢(n-1)n. And the bias is, (n-1)⁢σ2n-σ2=-σ2n. \hdashline

10.4 Mean Squared Error (MSE)

We are also interested in the accuracy of the statistic. One way of measuring this is through the mean squared error of the statistic. The MSE of an estimator g(X) for θ is defined by,

MSE⁢(g⁢(X¯))=E⁢[(g⁢(X¯)-θ)2].

This is not always the variance of g(X)

Var⁢(g⁢(X¯))=E⁢[{g⁢(X¯)-E⁢[g⁢(X¯)]}2].

The MSE is only equal to this variance when

E⁢[g⁢(X¯)]=θ   (i.e., when g(X) is unbiased).
MSE=Variance+Bias2.
This expression can be proved as follows:
𝑀𝑆𝐸⁢[g⁢(X¯)] = 𝐸⁢[(g⁢(X¯)-θ)2]
= 𝐸⁢[{(g⁢(X¯)-𝐸⁢[g⁢(X¯)])+(𝐸⁢[g⁢(X¯)]-θ)}2]
= 𝐸⁢[(g⁢(X¯)-𝐸⁢[g⁢(X¯)])2]+2⁢(𝐸⁢[g⁢(X¯)]-θ)⁢𝐸⁢[g⁢(X¯)-𝐸⁢[g⁢(X¯)]]
    +(𝐸⁢[g⁢(X¯)]-θ)2
= 𝑉𝑎𝑟⁢[g⁢(X¯)]+𝑏𝑖𝑎𝑠⁢(g⁢(X¯))2

Example 56
\hdashlineLet Xi (i=1,…,n) be i.i.d. normal with mean μ and variance σ2. We know that E⁢(S2)=σ2⁢ and Var⁢(S2)=2⁢σ4(n-1)=MSE⁢(S2). Also, consider E⁢[∑i(Xi-X¯)2n]=σ2⁢(n-1)n⁢ and Var⁢[∑i(Xi-X¯)2n]=2⁢(n-1)⁢σ4n2. Therefore, MSE⁢[∑i(Xi-X¯)2n]=(2⁢n-1)⁢σ4n2 < (2⁢n-1)⁢σ4n⁢(n-1) < 2⁢n⁢σ4n⁢(n-1)<MSE⁢(S2). Show final two slides of Sampling.pptx \hdashline

We can be biased and more accurate at the same time.

11 Confidence Intervals (CT3 Unit 10)

A confidence interval provides an ‘interval estimate’ of an unknown parameter (instead of just a ‘point estimate’). Therefore, we get some appreciation of the accuracy of the estimate.

A 100⁢(1-α)% confidence interval for θ is defined by specifying random variables θ^1⁢(X¯) and θ^2⁢(X¯) such that:

Pr(θ^1(X¯)<θ<θ^2(X¯))=1-α,

which gives the confidence interval:

(θ^1⁢(X¯),θ^2⁢(X¯)).

There are infinitely many choices for the random variables given α, so confidence intervals are not unique. The usual choice for α is α=0.05 so we will have a 95% confidence interval. In the long run, if we repeated the experiment that yielded X¯ and we calculate a 95% interval in the same manner, 95% of such intervals will contain θ.

11.1 Confidence Intervals for Normally Distributed Random Variables

If we are sampling from a N⁢(μ,σ2) with σ2 known, we know that

X¯-μσ2/n∼N⁢(0,1)

From tables, we know that

Pr(-1.96<X¯-μσ/n<1.96)=0.95
⇒ Pr(-1.96σn<X¯-μ<1.96σn)=0.95
⇒ Pr(-X¯-1.96σn<-μ<-X¯+1.96σn)=0.95
⇒ Pr(X¯-1.96σn<μ<X¯+1.96σn)=0.95
Figure of a normal curve, confidence interval shaded

This can also be written as X¯±1.96⁢σn.

If we look at the width of the interval, the larger n is (i.e., the more data we have), the more confidence we have in the estimate.

Powerpoint slides: CIs.pptx

Example 57
\hdashlineLet Xi∼i.i.d.N⁢(μ,3) and X¯={X1,X2,X3}, so that X¯∼N⁢(μ,1). Suppose x¯={-1,1,2} and x¯=23 We can construct a 95% confidence interval using X¯±1.96⁢σn so, approximately, we have (-1.3,2.6). In this example, we know that μ is really 0, so X¯∼N⁢(0,1), and we can calculate Pr(-1.3<X¯<2.6) = Pr(X¯<2.6)-Pr(X¯<-1.3) = 0.9953-0.0968 = 0.8985. \hdashline

Remember the following:

  • •

    A 95% confidence interval is not 95% probability that the statistic is inside that interval,

  • •

    It is not a 95% probability that the true parameter is in that interval.

  • •

    It is such that, if we repeated the same experiment many times and we constructed the confidence interval in the same way, 95% of such intervals would contain θ.

We can also get asymmetric confidence intervals:

Pr(-∞<X¯-μσ2/n<1.6449)=0.95,
⇒ Pr(X¯-1.6449σn<μ<∞)=0.95,
or Pr(X¯-1.8808σn<μ<X¯+2.0537σn)=0.95.

Example 58
\hdashlineWe wish to estimate the average percentage change in workforce over the past year for FTSE listed companies. From years of study, we know that they are normally distributed with variance of 3. We have access to this percentage change for just 10 companies. We have calculated x¯=0.14%. Find a 99% confidence interval for μ. We know Pr(Z<2.5758)=0.995 for Z∼N⁢(0,1). Hence, Pr( ¯ X -2.5758 3 10 ¡μ¡ ¯ X +2.5758 3 10 )=0.99 So, for our samples, a 99% confidence interval for μ is (-1.27%,1.55%), i.e. the width of the confidence interval is 2.82%. We decide that this confidence interval is not accurate enough. How many companies’ figures do we need to get a 99% confidence interval width of at most 1%? We have that width=2×2.5758⁢3n, ⇒ 1=2×2.5758×3n ⇒ n=2×2.5758×3 ⇒ n=79.617 Therefore, if we want to find a 99% CI of at most width 1, we need to get info from at least 80 companies. \hdashline

If we have the sampling distribution for a statistic, we can derive a confidence interval. Previously, we had

X¯-μS/n∼tn-1⁢ for ⁢Xi∼i.i.d.N⁢(μ,σ2),i=1,…,n, and ⁢μ,σ2⁢ unknown.

Here, a 95% confidence interval for μ is given by

X¯±t0.025,n-1⁢Sn.

We also had

(n-1)⁢S2σ2∼χn-12⁢ for same ⁢Xi.

Therefore, a 95% confidence interval for σ2 is

((n-1)⁢S2χ0.975,n-12,(n-1)⁢S2χ0.025,n-12).

Example 59
\hdashline(Workforce-change example continued) Now, let’s say we do not know the variance, but we still have data for 10 companies, x¯=0.14%,s2=3. Find a 99% confidence interval for μ. If T∼t9, Then Pr(T<3.2498)=0.995, so a 99% confidence interval for μ is given by ¯ x ±3.2498 3 10 ⇒(-1.64%,1.92%),        (which is a width of 3.56%). Find a 99% confidence interval for σ2, χ0.005,92 =1.7359 χ0.995,92 =23.5894 ⇒(1.14,15.56). \hdashline

11.2 Confidence intervals for two sample problems

A comparison of parameters for two populations can be considered by taking independent random samples from each population. When samples are independent,

Var⁢(X1¯-X2¯)=σ12n1+σ22n2.

If samples are not independent,

Var⁢(X1¯-X2¯)=σ12n1+σ22n2-2⁢Cov⁢(X1¯,X2¯).

So, in this case, the covariance could have a massive impact on the distribution of X1¯-X2¯ and the resulting confidence intervals.

11.2.1 Normal means

If x1¯ and x2¯ are means from independent random samples of size n1 and n2 (and we know that they follow normal distributions with variances σ12 and σ22), then a 100⁢(1-α)% confidence interval for the difference in population means μ1-μ2 is:

(x1¯-x2¯)±zα/2⁢σ12n1+σ22n2

where zα/2 is given by Pr(Z<zα/2)=(1-α2) and Z∼N⁢(0,1).
If σ12 and σ22 are unknown, but is it believed that σ12 =σ22, and we have sample statistics s12 and s22, then a 100⁢(1-α)% confidence interval for μ1-μ2 is:

(x¯1-x¯2)±tα/2,n1+n2-2⁢sp⁢1n1+1n2,

where sp2=(n1-1)⁢s12+(n2-1)⁢s22n1+n2-2 is the pooled variance.

Example 60
\hdashlineWe want to estimate the difference between the average salaries in (£⁢k) at two companies. We believe that the salaries are normally distributed and each population has the same variance, but we don’t know the variance: n1=20 n2=12 x¯1=31.5 x¯2=30.1 s12=4.1 s22=4.8 Then x¯1-x¯2=1.4, and sp2=19×4.1+11×4.820+12-2=4.356. This is closer to s12 because n1>n2. Also, t0.025,30=2.0423. Hence, the 95% confidence interval for μ1-μ2 is: 1.4±2.04234.356120+112,⇒(0.16,2.96) Roughly speaking, this confidence interval covers 0, so we cannot rule out μ1-μ2=0 or, equivalently, μ1=μ2. \hdashline

11.2.2 Two sample normal variances

For two population variances, we consider σ12σ22 rather than σ12-σ22.
We have that:

S12/σ12S22/σ22=S12/S22σ12/σ22∼ℱn1-1,n2-1,

which leads to a 95% confidence interval of:

S12S22×1ℱ0.975,n1-1,n2-1<σ12σ22<S12S22×ℱ0.975,n2-1,n1-1.
Let FP/100,n1-1,n2-1 be the Pth percentile of the F-distribution, then
ℱP/100,n1-1,n2-1=1ℱ1-P/100,n2-1,n1-1.

We will be looking for confidence intervals that include 1, that is because σ12/σ22=1⇒σ12=σ22.

Example 61
\hdashlineAssume we have two independent samples that come from normal distributions: n1=4, n2=5, s12=3.33 and s22=1.5. From tables (or R: qf), we know that ℱ0.975,3,4=9.98 and ℱ0.975,4,3=15.1. Therefore, a 95% CI for σ12/σ22 is given by (0.22,34) to 2 s.f.. \hdashline

12 Hypothesis Testing (CT3 Unit 11)

A hypothesis is a proposed possible explanation for a set of circumstances. For example, we might hypothesise that the mean value for some population is some specified value.

The basic hypothesis being tested is the null hypothesis (H0). In a hypothesis test, we contrast this with the alternative hypothesis (H1).
For example, H0:μ=0 vs. H1:μ≠0.

A test is a rule that divides the space of possible experimental results into two regions. In one region, the results are consistent with H0. In the other, they are not (this second region is the critical region).

The test answers the question ‘Do the data provide sufficient evidence to justify rejecting H0?’. For the test, we need to find a suitable test statistic for which we can define a distribution under the null hypothesis.
 
The level of significance of the test, α, is the probability of committing a type I error; that is, rejecting H0 when H0 is true.
 
The probability of committing a type II error is β. This is the probability of not rejecting H0 when it is false. (1-β) is called the power of the test.
 
An ideal test would minimise both α and β. In practice, this is difficult so we often fix α and pick a test that minimises β.

12.1 Single Sample Tests for Means

We have a sample from N⁢(μ,σ2), and we would like to know if it is reasonable to say μ=μ0.
So we have:

H0:μ=μ0⁢ vs. ⁢H1: μ≠μ0 two-sided
μ>μ0,μ<μ0 one-sided

If σ2 is known, our test statistic is:

Z=X¯-μ0σ/n∼N⁢(0,1)⁢ under ⁢H0, or ⁢X∼N⁢(μ0,σ2).

If σ2 is unknown, our test statistic is:

T=X¯-μ0s/n∼tn-1, under ⁢H0.

Example 62
\hdashlineWe have Xi∼i.i.d.N⁢(μ,3) and x¯={-1,1,2}. Our test is: H_0:μ=0 vs. H_1:μ≠0. Under H0,X¯3/3∼N⁢(0,1). We want to test at a 5% level of significance. The critical region is outside μ0±1.96=±1.96. [Diagram here showing critical region] Our test statistic z=(x¯-μ0)/σn=x¯=23. In this case, z=x¯: this is not always true. This is outside the critical region. Therefore, we do not have enough evidence to reject H0 at a 5% level. \hdashline

In general, the critical region is the complement of:

μ0±zα/2⁢σn for a 2-sided test and known ⁢σ2
or
μ0±tα/2,n-1⁢sn for a 2-sided test and unknown ⁢σ2.

Example 63
\hdashlineLet Xi∼i.i.d.N⁢(μ,3) and x¯={-1,1,2}. Our test is: H_0:μ=-1 vs. H_1:μ¿-1. Under H0,(X¯-(-1))3/3∼N⁢(0,1). We test at a 5% level of significance, and our critical region is X¯+1>1.6449. With our data, x¯+1=53=1.6˙, which is in the critical region. So we have enough evidence to reject H0 at the 5% level. \hdashline

Example 64
\hdashlineLet Xi∼i.i.d.N⁢(μ,σ2) and x¯={-1,1,2}. The sample variance is 7/3. Again, our test is: H_0:μ=-1 vs. H_1:μ¿-1. Under H0,(X¯-(-1))7/3/3∼t2. We test at a 5% level of significance, and our critical region is (X¯+1)/7/9>2.92. With our data, (x¯+1)/7/9=1.89 (to 2 d.p.), which is not in the critical region. So we do not have enough evidence to reject H0 at the 5% level. \hdashline

12.2 P-Value

We can also assess the strength of the rejection of H0 using the p-value.
The p-value is the probability of seeing a test statistic as extreme as the one in our experiment under the assumptions of H0.

12.2.1 What the p-value is not

  • •

    It is not the probability that H0 is true (or false).

  • •

    It is not the probability of getting the value of the test statistic.

Example 65
\hdashlineLet Xi∼i.i.d.N⁢(μ,3) and x¯={-1,1,2}, so x¯=23. (a) H0:μ=0⁢ vs. ⁢H1:μ≠0 Then to find the p-value: p⁢-value = Pr(|X¯|>23|H0), = Pr(X¯<-23|H0)+Pr(X¯>23|H0), = 0.2525+(1-0.7475), = 0.5050. So, under the null hypothesis, a value this extreme for the test statistic is not that unlikely. (b) H0:μ=-1⁢ vs. ⁢H1:μ>-1 Then to find the p-value: p⁢-value = Pr(X¯>23|H0), = 0.0478. Hence, the p-value<0.05. So we can reject H0 at the 5% level, but, as p-value>0.01, we cannot reject H0 at the 1% level. \hdashline

12.3 Single Sample Tests for Variance

We have a sample of size n from N⁢(0,1). Our hypothesis will be:

H0:σ2=σ02⁢ vs. ⁢H1:σ2≠σ02.

The test statistic is:

(n-1)⁢S2σ02∼χn-12, under ⁢H0.

Example 66
\hdashlineLet Xi∼i.i.d.N⁢(μ,σ2),i=1,…,15⁢ with ⁢s2=23.2. We test: H_0:σ^2=10 vs. H_1:σ^2¿10. We might want to test at a 1% level of significance. Now, 14⁢s210>χ0.99,142=29.14 As s2=23.2,1410×23.2=32.48>29.14. Hence, there is enough evidence at the 1% level to reject H0. In this case, p-value=Pr( 14s 2 10 ¿32.48—H_0)=0.0038¡1%. \hdashline

12.4 Two-sample tests for population means and variances

We have independent samples of size n1 and n2 from N⁢(μ1,σ12) and N⁢(μ2,σ22) respectively, and we will consider:

H0: μ1-μ2=δ
vs.
H1: μ1-μ2≠δ

If σ12 and σ22 are known, the test statistic under H0 is

Z=X1¯-X2¯-δσ12n1+σ22n2∼N⁢(0,1).

If σ12 and σ22 are unknown, but we are assuming that σ12=σ22, then under H0,

T=X1¯-X2¯-δSp⁢1n1+1n2∼tn1+n2-2,

where the pooled variance is

Sp2=(n1-1)⁢S12+(n2-1)⁢S22n1+n2-2.

This is the two-sample t-test.

For variances, a suitable test might be:

H0:σ12=σ22⁢ vs. ⁢H1:σ12≠σ22

Here, under H0, the test statistic is simply:

S12S22∼ℱn1-1,n2-1.

This is a formal test for the equal variances needed for the two-sampled t-test.

In what we have looked at so far, an important consideration is whether the two samples from each population are independent. However, this is not always the case.

Example 67
\hdashlineConsider a random sample of companies, which we have recorded profits for 2010 and 2011: Company 2010 (£k) 2011 (£k) A 33 29 B 32 28 C 27 41 ⋮ ⋮ ⋮ Note that the 2011 sample depends upon the sample shown for 2010. We might be interested in whether the mean profit is the same across the two years: H_0:μ_2010=μ_2011 vs. H_1:μ_2010≠μ_2011 When we have paired data, we consider differences instead: δ=μ2011-μ2010 to give the new test: H_0:δ=0 vs. H_1:δ≠0 When data is paired, you take the difference between the two years, and treat as one sample test. We might say that δ∼N⁢(0,σ2) under the null hypothesis. \hdashline

12.5 χ2 tests

This type of test is used to test the hypothesis that a variable follows some specified distribution. It depends on us having count data for the random variables of interest and a way of calculating the expected count given the specified distribution.

Example 68
\hdashlineWe are testing if a six-sided die is fair. A suitable model is: P(X=x)= 1 6 ,      x=1,2,…,6. We have the test: H0: X⁢ has this uniform distribution, vs. H1: X⁢ does 𝐧𝐨𝐭 have this distribution, We are going to assume that we have a simple random sample (independent). I throw the die 300 times to get: x: 1 2 3 4 5 6 fi: 43 56 54 47 41 59 ei: 50 50 50 50 50 50 fi-ei: -7 6 4 -3 -9 9 (fi-ei)2 49 36 16 9 81 81 Our test statistic is: ∑[(fi-ei)2ei]   ⋅ ∼   ⋅ χk-12, where k is the number of possible values of x (k=6). In this case, ∑_i=1^6[ ( f i -e i ) 2 e i ]=5.44. Under H0: ∑[(fi-ei)2ei]∼χ52, and from tables, if Y∼χ52, P(Y>11.070)=0.05. So 5.44 is well outside the critical region (at the 5% level). Therefore, we do not have enough evidence to reject that the die is fair. \hdashline

12.6 Contingency Tables

Draw a 2-way contingency table (maybe use example 70)

A contingency table is a two-way table of counts obtained when sample observations are classified according to two categorical variables. In this case, the null hypothesis is:

H0: the two classification criteria are independent,
     vs.
H1: the two classification criteria have some dependence.

The test statistic is essentially a comparison between observed values in the table and values that we would expect to get if the criteria were independent. Expected value of cell in table =(row total × column total)table total.

Example 69
\hdashline Consider results from a job survey. North South Total Agriculture 6 4 10 Industry 18 12 30 Office 36 24 60 Total 60 40 100 Talk about maintaining proportions. \hdashline

Now, our test statistic is given by

∑cells of the table[(fi-ei)2ei]   ⋅ ∼   ⋅ χk2.

where the degrees of freedom k=(Number of rows-1)×(Number of columns-1).

Example 70
\hdashlineA job survey was conducted for 200 individuals, with the following results: Job Category fi Unskilled Skilled Professional Unemployed Total School 34 22 8 8 72 College 18 18 33 5 74 University 3 13 31 7 54 Total 55 53 72 20 200 We have: H0: Education is independent of job category vs. H1: Education is not independent of job category As expected frequency=(row total × column total)table total, we get: Job Category ei Unskilled Skilled Professional Unemployed Total School 19.80 19.08 25.92 7.20 72 College 20.35 19.61 26.64 7.40 74 University 14.85 14.31 19.44 5.4 54 Note that: Degrees of freedom = 6. In this case, ∑[(fi-ei)2ei]=42.73, then, if Y∼χ62,P(Y>42.73)=0.0000001. Therefore, we can reject H0 at a 5% (or 1%, or even 0.0001%) level. \hdashline

Note: The χ2 distribution is an approximation here. If any ei is small, then it is a poor approximation. By small, we should avoid ei<5. If you get ei<5, you may need to combine categories or drop them all together.

13 Correlation and Regression (CT3 Unit 12)

We use correlation to measure the strength of linear relationships between two variables. This is closely related to the problem of fitting a straight line through some data points. The process of fitting a straight line is called linear regression.
In linear regression, we use a straight line to describe the relationship between y, the response (or dependent) variable, and x, the explanatory (or independent) variable.

Example 71
\hdashlineThis example is taken from the CT3 book (unit 12, page 3). A sample of ten claims and corresponding payments on settlement for household policies is taken from the business of an insurance company. The amounts are in units of £100. We denote the claim by x and the corresponding payment by y. Now, move to the slides: Correlation and regression.pptx. \hdashline

13.1 Correlation

We are going to use the following samples statistics throughout this section:

Sx⁢x =∑i=1n(xi-x¯)2=∑xi2-(∑xi)2n=∑xi2-n⁢x¯2,
Sy⁢y =∑i=1n(yi-y¯)2=∑yi2-(∑yi)2n=∑yi2-n⁢y¯2,
(Sy⁢x=) Sx⁢y =∑i=1n(xi-x¯)⁢(yi-y¯)=∑xi⁢yi-(∑xi)⁢(∑yi)n
=∑xi⁢yi-n⁢x¯⁢y¯,

where we have n observations of Xi,Yi pairs.

Derive the relationship for Sx⁢y and relate to variance and covariance.

Correlation is defined as

r=Cov⁢(X,Y)Var⁢(X)⁢Var⁢(Y)=Sx⁢ySx⁢x⁢Sy⁢y.

Correlation, r, must be between [-1,1]. If r is close to 1, there is a strong positive correlation.

Powerpoint slides: Correlation.pptx

We have |Sx⁢y|≤max⁢{Sx⁢x,Sy⁢y}, because |r|≤1.

Example 72
\hdashlineContinuation of example 72: see slides. \hdashline

13.2 The Simple Linear Model

Given a set of n pairs of data (xi,yi),i=1,…,n; the yi are regarded as a response random variable Yi given xi. For the purpose of this type of analysis, the xi, the values of the explanatory variable, are regarded as constants.
The simple linear model is the following relationship:

Yi=α+β⁢xi+ei,i=1,…,n,

where the ei are uncorrelated with mean 0 and have common variance σ2; i.e., E⁢(ei)=0, Var⁢(ei)=σ2 and Cov⁢(ei,ej)=0,∀i≠j. Note that:

E⁢[Yi|xi] = E⁢[α+β⁢xi+ei]
= E⁢[α]+E⁢[β⁢xi]+E⁢[ei]
= α+β⁢xi.

Here, β is the slope parameter and α is the intercept. To fit the model, we must estimate α,β and σ2. The fitted regression line (or fitted model) that we can use to estimate Y given x is given by

y^=α^+β^⁢x,

where

β^=Sx⁢ySx⁢x

and

α^=y¯-β^⁢x¯.

These estimates come from minimising the sum of squared errors for the regression model (exercise).

We want to find α and β such that ∑i=1n(y^i-yi)2 is minimised. Let’s set
h⁢(α,β) = ∑i=1n[(α+β⁢xi)-yi]2,
∂⁡h⁢(α,β)∂⁡α = ∑i=1n2⁢(α+β⁢xi-yi),
set this to zero: ⁢∑i=1nyi = n⁢α^+β^⁢∑i=1nxi
⟹α^ = y¯-β^⁢x¯.
∂⁡h⁢(α,β)∂⁡β = ∑i=1n2⁢xi⁢(α+β⁢xi-yi),
set to zero & sub in α^: ⁢∑i=1nxi⁢yi-y¯⁢∑i=1nxi = β^⁢(∑i=1nxi2-x¯⁢∑i=1nxi)
⟹β^ = Sx⁢y/Sx⁢x.
We could also perform the second partial derivative test to check it is a minimum.
Powerpoint slides: Correlation and regression.pptx

The estimate for the error variance is:

σ^2=1n-2⁢∑i=1n(yi-y^i)2=1n-2⁢∑ri2,

where ri=(yi-y^i) are the residuals from the fitted model.

Warning: Lookout for outliers as they can give regression line leverage and skew data.

We also have that β^ is the observed value of a statistic B^, whose sampling distribution has the properties:

E⁢(B^) = β,
Var⁢(B^) = σ2Sx⁢x.

To help understand the ‘goodness of fit’ of our model to the data, we investigate the total variation in the response, which is Sy⁢y=∑(yi-y¯)2.
In particular, we want to know how much of the variation can be explained by our model as opposed to random variables. We look at departures from predicted responses:

yi-y¯ = (yi-y^i)+(y^i-y¯),
which gives,
(yi-y¯)2 = [(yi-y^i)+(y^i-y¯)]2,

and, using ∑i=1n(yi-y^i)=0, we can get:

Sy⁢y=∑(yi-y¯)2= ∑(yi-y^i)2+∑(y^i-y¯)2.
i.e.,
Total sum of squares= Residual sum of squares+Regression sum of squares

Note: This is sometimes written as SST=SSR+SSE, or TSS=RSS+ERR.

SST = sum of squares in total, SSR = sum of squares explained by the regression, SSE = sum of squares for the errors. TSS = total sum of squares, RSS = regression sum of squares, ERR = error sum of squares

We will use SSTOT=SSRES+SSREG. For computation,

SSTOT= Sy⁢y
SSREG= ∑i=1n[(α^+β^⁢xi)-(α^+β^⁢x¯)]2=Sx⁢y2Sx⁢x
SSRES= Sy⁢y-Sx⁢y2Sx⁢x

For this model, the level of correlation between X and Y is highly related to the goodness of fit. The proportion of the total variability in y is explained by the linear model and is called the coefficient of determination,

R2=SSREGSSTOT=Sx⁢y2Sx⁢x⁢Sy⁢y.

Note that:

  • •

    If R=1, the model provides a perfect fit,

  • •

    If R=0, the model is doing nothing,

  • •

    For a linear model, R2 is the square of the correlation coefficient.

Powerpoint slides: Correlation and regression (part 2).pptx

Example 73
\hdashlineContinuing the earlier example, we have SSTOT = 7.159, SSREG = 6.573 and SSRES = 0.586. And the coefficient of determination is 91.8%. \hdashline

13.3 The Normal Linear Model

We have already seen that β^ is a sample statistic for some statistic B^, which has E⁢[B^]=β and Var⁢(B^)=σ2Sx⁢x.
We might want to test if B^ is significantly different from zero, and, to do this, we need to make assumptions about the distributions of the errors.
Our model is:

Yi=α+β⁢xi+ei,

and, now, because we have ei∼i.i.d.N⁢(0,σ2), it follows that given xi, the Yi are normally distributed random variables with

E⁢[Yi] = α+β⁢xi,
Var⁢(Yi) = σ2.

It can be shown that B^∼N⁢(β,σ2Sx⁢x), B^ and σ2 are independent, and (n-2)⁢σ^2σ2∼χn-22.
Now, if σ2 is known,

B^-β(σ2/Sx⁢x)12∼N⁢(0,1).

Of course, this is rarely the case and, because B^ and σ^2 are independent,

B^-β(σ2/Sx⁢x)12[((n-2)⁢σ^2σ2)/(n-2)]12∼tn-2
⇒   B^-β(σ^2/Sx⁢x)12∼tn-2.

Using this distribution, we can calculate confidence intervals for β and test hypotheses like H0:β=0⁢ vs. ⁢H1:β≠0.

Example 74
\hdashlineA 95% CI for β is given by β^±t0.025,n-2⁢(σ^2Sx⁢x)1/2. In our example, β^=0.8823,σ^2=0.0732,Sx⁢x=8.444 and n=10. From tables, t0.025,8=-2.306. Therefore, a 95% CI for β is 0.8823±2.306⁢(0.0732/8.444)1/2=0.8823±0.2147, or (0.6676, 1.0970). Consider the following hypothesis test at the 1% level of significance: H0:β=0⁢ vs. ⁢H1:β≠0. Under H0, B^(σ^2/Sx⁢x)12∼t8. Using a two-sided test, we will reject the null hypothesis if |β^(σ^2/Sx⁢x)1/2|>3.355 (which is the 99.5% point of a t8 distribution). Our test statistic is 9.476 to 3 d.p.. Therefore, we have enough evidence to reject the hypothesis that β=0. In terms of our problem, this means that our data give support to a (positive) linear relationship between claim value and the amount paid out by the insurer. \hdashline

13.4 Using our model to estimate mean responses and to predict individual responses

Let μ* be the expected response for a value x*:

μ*=E⁢[Y|x*]=α+β⁢x*,

μ* is estimated by μ^*=α^+β^⁢x*, and the variance of this estimator is

Var⁢(μ^*)={1n+(x*-x¯)2Sx⁢x}⁢σ^2.

We can find:

(μ^*-μ*)s.e.⁢(μ^*)∼tn-2,

where the standard error of μ^* is:

s.e.⁢(μ^*)=[{1n+(x*-x¯)2Sx⁢x}⁢σ^2]12.

This can be used to produce confidence intervals for μ*.
Instead of considering the mean response, we sometimes need to look at predicted responses for some x*, which we denote y*.
The estimate is:

y^*=α^*+β^⁢x*.

However, the uncertainty associated with this estimate is greater. In this case,

(y^*-y*)s.e.⁢(y^*)∼tn-2,

where

s.e.⁢(y^*)=[{1+1n+(x*-x¯)2Sx⁢x}⁢σ^2]12.

Example 75
\hdashlineWe are interested in estimating what we pay on average and variability there could be in payouts when people are claiming £350. μ* = α^+β^⁢x* = 0.1636+0.8823×3.5=£⁢325.17=y^*. s.e.⁢(μ^*) = [(1n+(x*-x¯)2Sx⁢x)⁢σ^2]1/2=0.086. s.e.⁢(y^*) = [(1+1n+(x*-x¯)2Sx⁢x)⁢σ^2]1/2=0.284. The standard error is three times bigger for the possible value of prediction rather than the mean. \hdashline

13.5 Multiple Linear Regression

An extension of the simple linear model is made by allowing for multiple explanatory variables:

Yi=α+β1⁢xi⁢1+β2⁢xi⁢2+…+βk⁢xi⁢k+ei,i=1,…,n.

with ei∼i.i.d.N⁢(0,σ2).

We end up with very similar sampling distributions that enable us to test if βi=0 or not. We can also use the same sum of squares partition to get the population of variance explained by the model.

14 ANalysis Of VAriance (ANOVA) (CT3 Unit 13)

A ‘one-way analysis of variance’ (or one-way ANOVA) is used to compare k ‘treatments’ when an experiment provides ni responses for treatment i, i=1,…,k. The data are then n(=∑ini) responses yi⁢j, where yi⁢j is the jt⁢h observation for the it⁢h treatment. ‘Treatment’ for us could mean company, country, employment status, etc..
Essentially, we want to know if there is a difference in the mean response across the differential treatments. The model is:

Yi⁢j=μ+τi+ei⁢j, i=1,…,k,j=1,…,n, ei⁢j∼i.i.d.N⁢(0,σ2).

We define the overall mean to be:

μ=1n⁢∑i∑jE⁢[Yi⁢j]

and τi is the difference made on average by treatment i.
Estimation of the parameters follows a least-squares maximisation procedure:

μ^ = Y¯∙∙⁢where⁢Y¯∙∙=1n⁢∑i∑jYi⁢j
τ^i = Y¯i⁣∙-Y¯∙∙⁢where⁢Y¯i⁣∙=1ni⁢∑j=1nYi⁢j.
Also,  σ^2 = 1n-k⁢∑i∑j(Yi⁢j-Y¯i⁣∙)2
and 1σ2⁢∑i∑j(Yi⁢j-Y¯i⁣∙)2∼χn-k2.

Again, we partition the variability:

∑i∑j(Yi⁢j-Y¯∙∙)2 = ∑i∑j(Yi⁢j-Y¯i⁣∙)2+∑ini⁢(Y¯i⁣∙-Y¯∙∙)2.
(SSTOT =     SSRES    +   SSTRE)

A typical hypothesis test for this type of model is:

H0:τi=0, i=1,…,k,
vs.
H1:τi≠0, for at least one ⁢i.

It can be shown that, under H0,

F = [SSTREk-1]/[SSRESn-k]
= Between treatment mean squared errorResidual mean squared error

and F∼ℱk-1,n-k. We reject H0 if F is large.
We usually set out the components of this test in an ANOVA table:

Source of variation Degrees of freedom Sum of squares Mean Squares F-statistic
Between treatments k-1 SSTRE SSTREk-1 SSTRE×(n-k)SSRES×(k-1)
Residual n-k SSRES SSRESn-k
Total n-1 SSTOT

Example 76
\hdashlineWe have 5 companies and we want to know if accountants within each company have significantly different average salaries: H0:τi=0, i=1,…,5 vs. H1:τi≠0, for at least one ⁢i The ANOVA table gives: Source of variation Degrees of freedom Sum of squares Mean Squares F-statistic Between treatments 4 128.9 32.23 1.85 Residual 45 782.2 17.38 Total 49 911.1 From tables, ℱ4,45⁢(95%)=2.58. 1.85<2.58 so we don’t have enough evidence at the 5% level to reject H0. \hdashline

15 Assessing Model Fit Numerically

When we have several competing models, there are many metrics available to help us decide which model is ‘best’. If we are simply interested in how well a model fits data, we may consider the root mean squared-errors (RMSE):

MSE = 1n⁢∑i=1n(y^i-yi)2,
RMSE = MSE.

We might be interested in finding the model with smallest RMSE. In general, the more variables/parameters that we add to our model, the lower the RMSE, regardless of whether the variables are related or if the extra parameters explain the variation (this is called overfitting).

Diagram demonstrating overfitting

15.1 Information Criteria

The Akaike information criterion (AIC) provides a way of judging models that takes into account the number of parameters being used as well as the fit. We use the following formula:

AIC=2⁢k-2⁢ln⁢(l*),

where k is the number of parameters and l* is the maximised likelihood for the fitted model.

Again, we want to minimise AIC. AIC is smaller for simpler models (small k) and for models with larger maximum likelihood.
There is another metric that penalises for the number of parameters even more: the Baysian Information Criterion (BIC):

BIC=ln⁢(n)⁢k-2⁢ln⁢(l*).

where n is the number of observations. (If n>8, BIC will be larger than AIC.) We try to find the model with the smallest BIC.

Example 77
\hdashlineFit three different models to 50 observations. Model No. of parameters l* RMSE AIC BIC 1 3 8.28 0.4821 1.77 9.58 2 6 14.16 0.4511 6.70 18.7 3 100 18.31 0.0026 194.19 385.39 From this table, we can see we penalise the model where we use 100 parameters. In this example, there are 50 observations and 100 parameters: we should not use this model. \hdashline

15.2 Cross-validation

An alternative approach to avoiding over-fitting— and to make comparisons between models — which does not inherently favour a specific model assumption, is to use cross-validation.

The main idea is to split the n observations into two complementary sets: a training or learning set, say L⊂{1,…,n} and a test set, say T={1,…,n}∩Lc. Any model or procedure is then fit to the data in L, but then models are compared using the data in T. To give an example, a regression model (which could be nonparametric) could be fit to observations (xi,yi),i∈L and then the model could be used to predict y for each xi,i∈T, giving y^i,i∈T. Then comparisons can be made by considering

∑{i,i∈T}(yi-y^i)2.

Such an approach can be used for selecting smoothing parameters, by successively choosing T={1},T={2},…,T={n} and this is known as “leave-one-out cross-validation”.

For the purposes of model or method comparisons it would be common to choose the size of L to be approximately n/2, with observations selected at random from the original set. When forecasting is the objective (as in the next chapter) it would then be more natural to take the test set T to be the latest observations available.

16 Time Series (Brooks Ch 5)

A time series is a set of variables (or data) that are indexed by some notion of time.
 
Examples:

  • •

    Daily close price for some stock,

  • •

    Monthly interest rates for some national bank (time refers to month),

  • •
