    Stock price after trades (time is ordering or trades).

A time series model is a model that uses past time series observations to provide a mechanism to predict future values; for example, using historical stock data to predict future prices. The time series models we will be looking at will not contain any external explanatory variables. Our models are just based on past observations (this is called an empirical approach to modelling).

16.1 Notation and Important Concepts

Our time series are sequences of random variables:

…,X0,X1,X2,…⁢ or ⁢…,Y0,Y1,Y2,…,

or, once they have been observed, sequences of data values:

x0,x1,x2,…,xn⁢ or ⁢y0,y1,y2,…⁢yn.

We also have the concept of lag. There is a lag of 1 between x1 and x2, a lag of 2 between x5 and x7, etc.. In general, there is a lag of s between xk and xk+s.

A strictly stationary process is a time series where for any time indices and integer k,

FYt1,Yt2,…⁢Ytr⁢(y1,…,yr)=FYt1+k,Yt2+k,…⁢Ytr+k⁢(y1,…,yr)

That is, the joint distribution of the variables making up the time series does not change over time.
A weakly stationary process is a time series such that:

E⁢[Yt] = μ,∀t,
Var⁢(Yt) = σ2<∞,∀t,
Cov⁢(Yt1,Yt2) = γt2-t1,∀t1,t2.

The autocovariance between two time points t2>t1 is

γt2-t1=Cov⁢(Yt1,Yt2).

The autocorrelation at lag s is given by

τs=γs/γ0

if we have a weakly stationary process.
 
“Auto-” comes from the Greek for self.

The partial autocorrelation at lag s, denoted by αs, is the autocorrelation between Yt and Yt+s with the linear dependence of Yt+1 to Yt+s-1 removed. It can also be thought of as the autocorrelation between Yt and Yt+s that is not accounted for by the autocorrelation at lags 1 to s-1.

Think about a perfect linear relationship between two neighbouring variables in a time series. What does this mean for autocorrelation and partial autocorrelation?

There are three main plots that we will consider when analysing time series:

  1. 1.

    Data value vs. time

  2. 2.

    Autocorrelation vs. lag

  3. 3.

    Partial autocorrelation vs. lag

All of these can be used to help select a time series model.

Diagram showing plot types: Univariate time series.pptx

16.2 White Noise Process

The model is:

Xt=εt, εt∼i.i.d.Gε⁢(0,σε2)

where Gε is any distribution (t,ℱ,…) that satisfies some properties that are given below. Note that σε2 is the only parameter. We have Gaussian white noise if Gε⁢(0,σε2)=N⁢(0,σε2).

White noise processes have the following properties:

  1. 1.

    E⁢(Xt)=0,∀t,

  2. 2.

    Var⁢(Xt)=σε2,∀t,

  3. 3.

    Cov⁢(Xt,Xt+k)=0,∀t,k≠0.

Explain consequences of each

16.3 Autoregressive Process

An autoregressive process model of order p, AR(p), is:

Xt=c+∑i=1pϕi⁢Xt-i+εt, εt∼i.i.d.Gε⁢(0,σε2),

where ϕ1,…,ϕp,c,σε2 are model parameters.
 
Consider an AR(1) model such that Xt=c+ϕ1⁢Xt-1+εt, then

  1. 1.

    E⁢[Xt]=c+ϕ1⁢E⁢[Xt-1],
    but E⁢[Xt-1]=c+ϕ1⁢E⁢[Xt-2],
    so,

    E⁢[Xt] = c+ϕ1⁢(c+ϕ1⁢E⁢[Xt-2])
    = c⁢(1+ϕ1+ϕ12+…).

    Now, if |ϕ1|<1, this is a geometrically decreasing sum and

    E⁢[Xt]=c1-ϕ1.
  2. 2.

    For variance,

    Var⁢(Xt) = ϕ12⁢Var⁢(Xt-1)+σε2
    = σε2(1-ϕ12)

    if and only if |ϕ1|<1.

  3. 3.

    Similarly, for autocovariances at lag s,

    Cov⁢(Xt,Xt+s)=γs=ϕ1s⁢σε2(1-ϕ12),

    and the autocorrelation at lag s is

    ρs = γsγ0=Cov⁢(Xt,Xt+s)Var⁢(Xt)⁢Var⁢(Xt+s)
    = ϕ1s.

Example 78
\hdashlineConsider the AR(1) model. What is the autocovariance at lag 1? Cov⁢(Xt,Xt+1) = Cov⁢(Xt,c+ϕ1⁢Xt+εt+1), = Cov⁢(Xt,c)+Cov⁢(Xt,ϕ1⁢Xt)+Cov⁢(Xt,εt+1) = ϕ1⁢Cov⁢(Xt,Xt), = ϕ1⁢Var⁢(Xt), = ϕ1⁢σε2(1-ϕ12). \hdashline

Powerpoint slides: Univariate time series.pptx

More generally, we now consider the acf and pacf of the AR(p) model. If it is stationary then E⁢[Xt]=μ for all t and so

μ=E⁢[Xt] = c+ϕ1⁢E⁢[Xt-1]+⋯+ϕp⁢E⁢[Xt-p]+E⁢[εt]
= c+∑i=1pϕi⁢μ

and so

μ⁢(1-ϕ1-⋯-ϕp)=c (1)

and

μ=E⁢[Xt]=c1-ϕ1-⋯-ϕp.

Note that the condition for an AR(p) process to be stationary is that the roots of Φ⁢(B)=0 lie outside the unit circle, where Φ⁢(B) is defined by

Φ⁢(B)⁢Xt=(1-ϕ1⁢B-ϕ2⁢B2-⋯-ϕp⁢Bp)⁢Xt=Xt-ϕ1⁢Xt-1-⋯-ϕp⁢Xt-p

and B is known as the “backshift operator” (see Section 16.9).

To obtain the covariances (and then the autocorrelations) we first note that — using (1) —

Xt-μ=∑i=1pϕi⁢Bi⁢(Xt-μ)+εt

and so, without loss of generality, we can set μ=0 and replace Xt-μ by Xt. Then

γk=E⁢[Xt⁢Xt-k] = ∑i=1pϕi⁢E⁢[Xt⁢Xt-k]+E⁢[Xy-k⁢εt]
= ∑i=1pϕi⁢γk-i  for k>0

where we note that γk=γ-k.

Dividing by γ0=Var⁢[Xt] gives a recursive relationship

ρk=ϕ1ρk-1+⋯ϕpρk-p  (k>0).

The partial autocorrelation can be derived as follows. Consider the regression model where Xt+k is regressed on Xt+k-1,…,Xt, i.e.

Xt+k=ϕk⁢1⁢Xt+k-1+⋯+ϕk⁢k⁢Xt+εt+k

where the subscripts on ϕ show both the number of regressors (k) and the coefficient label (1,…,k). Mutiplying through by Xt, taking expectations, and proceeding as above, we obtain

ρj=ϕk⁢1⁢ρj-1+⋯+ϕk⁢k⁢ρj-k.

Thus for k=1,2,… gives a system of equations:

ρ1=ϕk⁢1⁢ρ0+⋯+ϕk⁢k⁢ρk-1⋮=⋮⋮ρk=ϕk⁢1⁢ρk-1+⋯+ϕk⁢k⁢ρ0

(where ρ0=1).

Using Cramer’s rule, we can solve (for k=1,2,…) to obtain

ϕ11 = ρ1
ϕ22 = |1ρ1ρ1ρ2||1ρ1ρ11|=ρ2-ρ121-ρ12
⋮ ⋮
ϕk⁢k = |1ρ1⋯ρk-2ρ1⋮⋮⋮⋮ρk-1ρk-2⋯ρ1ρk||1ρ1⋯ρk-2ρk-1⋮⋮⋮⋮ρk-1ρk-2⋯ρ11|

We can obtain the pacf for the AR(p) model we note that, when k>p the last column in the numerator of ϕk⁢k can be written as a linear combination of previous columns, and so the determinant will be zero, and so we see that, for an AR(p) process

ϕk⁢k=0  for k>p.

16.4 Moving average process

A moving average model of order q, MA(q), is

Xt=c+εt+∑i=1qθi⁢εt-i, εt∼i.i.d.Gε⁢(0,σε2),

where all error terms are independent and c,θ1,…,θq,σε2 are model parameters.

Consider MA(1),

Xt = c+εt+θ1⁢εt-1,
E⁢[Xt] = c,
Var⁢(Xt) = σε2+θ12⁢σε2=σε2⁢(1+θ12).

We also have

Cov⁢(Xt,Xt+1) = γ1
= Cov⁢(c+εt+θ1⁢εt-1,c+εt+1+θ1⁢εt)
= θ1⁢Cov⁢(εt,εt)
= θ1⁢σε2,

because Cov⁢(εt,εt)=σε2 and Cov⁢(c,c)=Cov⁢(εt,εt-1)=0.

Further,

ρ1=θ11+θ12,ρs=0     ∀s>1.

More generally, we consider the MA(q) process. Using similar calculations as for the AR(p) process we see that, if

Xt-μ=(1+∑i=1qθi⁢Bi)⁢εt

then

σX2=Var⁢[Xt]=γ0=σε2⁢∑i=0qθi2  with θ0=1

and

γk={σε2⁢(θk+θ1⁢θk+1+⋯+θq-k⁢θq)k=1,…,q0k>q

and so

ρk={θk+θ1⁢θk+1+⋯+θq-k⁢θq1+θ12+⋯+θq2k=1,…,q0k>q

16.5 Autoregressive Moving Average Process

An autoregressive moving average model with integer parameters p and q, ARMA(p,q) is

Xt=c+εt+∑i=1pϕi⁢Xt-i+∑i=1qθi⁢εt-i, εt∼i.i.d.Gε⁢(0,σε2),

where c,θ1,…,θq,σε2,ϕ1,…,ϕp are model parameters. Consider ARMA(1,2):

Xt = c+εt+ϕ1⁢Xt-1+θ1⁢ϵt-1+θ2⁢ϵt-2,
E⁢[Xt] = c+ϕ1⁢E⁢[Xt-1],
= c1-ϕ1,
Var⁢(Xt) = σε2+Var⁢(ϕ1⁢Xt-1+θ1⁢ϵt-1+θ2⁢ϵt-2).

Because Xt-1,εt-1 and εt-2 are related, it is not simple to derive this.

16.6 Identifying which model to use

We could use the acf(.) and pacf(.) plots to help identify models to fit.
For an AR(p) model:

acf: magnitude decreases geometrically,
       pacf: no significant partial autocorrelation after lag p.

For a MA(q) model:

acf: no significant autocorrelation after lag q,
       pacf: magnitude decreases geometrically.

For a ARMA(p,q):

acf: like acf for AR model after first few lags,
       pacf: like pacf for MA model after first few lags.

We can also use model selection criteria, AIC and BIC, to help select our model.

16.7 Model Checking

Choosing a good model for a set of data is not always easy, so it is important to compare models (for example using AIC), and then to check that the residuals from a fitted model form a white noise process. This can be checked by plotting the residuals, plotting an acf of the residuals, and using the Box-Pierce or Ljung-Box “portmanteau” tests, for which the test statistics are given by

Q=n⁢∑k=1Kρ^k2

and

Q=n⁢(n+2)⁢∑k=1K(n-k)-1⁢ρ^k2

respectively. Here, K is a user-chosen number to reflect the number of lags which are to be considered, and the statistic is compared to a χ2 distribution with K-p-q degrees of freedom.

16.8 Forecasting with Time Series Models

Often, we will want to ask: what value do we expect our time series to take several steps ahead? One way to think about this is to work out what the expectation and variance for the time series are several steps ahead. If we do it this way, then we have a point estimate and some appreciation of its accuracy.

Example 79
\hdashlineConsider the AR(2) model: Xt=c+ϕ1⁢Xt-1+ϕ2⁢Xt-2+εt. We know that c=0,ϕ1=0.2,ϕ2=-0.5 and σε2=1 (we will denote these by 𝒫). We observe x0=0.5,x1=0.9. What are x2,x3,x4? E⁢[X2|x0,x1,𝒫] = (0.2)⁢(0.9)-(0.5)⁢(0.5), = -0.07, Var⁢(X2|x0,x1,𝒫) = σε2=1, E⁢[X3|x0,x1,𝒫] = ϕ⁢E⁢[X2|x0,x1,𝒫]+ϕ2⁢x1, = (0.2)⁢(-0.07)+(-0.5)⁢(0.9), = -0.464, Var⁢(X3|x0,x1,𝒫) = ϕ12⁢Var⁢(X2|x0,x1,𝒫)+σε2, = 0.04+1, = 1.04. The further away we go away from 0, the more uncertain we are that σ2 will increase: E⁢[X4|x0,x1,𝒫] = (0.2)⁢(-0.464)+(-0.5)⁢(-0.07), = -0.0578 Var⁢(X4|x0,x1,𝒫) is more complicated due to the covariance between X2 and X3. Var⁢(X4|x0,x1,𝒫) = Var⁢(ϕ1⁢X3+ϕ2⁢X2|x0,x1,𝒫)+σε2, Var⁢(ϕ1⁢X3+ϕ2⁢X2|x0,x1,𝒫) = ϕ12⁢Var⁢(X3)+ϕ22⁢Var⁢(X2)     +2⁢ϕ1⁢ϕ2⁢Cov⁢(X2,X3), Cov⁢(X2,X3) = Cov⁢(X2,c+ϕ1⁢X2+ϕ2⁢x1+ε3) = ϕ1⁢Var⁢(X2), Var⁢(X4|x0,x1,𝒫) = σε2+ϕ12⁢Var⁢(X3)+(ϕ22+ϕ1)⁢Var⁢(X2) = 1+(0.2)2⁢1.04+(0.52+0.2)⁢1=1.4916. As t increases, E⁢[Xt|x0,x1,𝒫] will tend to the mean of the process and Var⁢(Xt|x0,x1,𝒫) will grow until we lose memory of the given points. \hdashline

Example 80
\hdashlineConsider the MA(1) model, Xt=c+θ1⁢ϵt-1+ϵt. We are given that {c=3,θ1=0.5,σε2=4}. If we know x0=3.5,x1=3.9,ε0=0.2,ε1=0.8, then: E⁢[X2|x0,x1,𝒫] = 3+(0.5)⁢(0.8), = 3.4, Var⁢(X2|x0,x1,𝒫) = σε2, = 4, E⁢[X3|x0,x1,𝒫] = 3(=c), Var⁢(X3|x0,x1,𝒫) = (1+θ12)⁢σε2. = 5 As t increases, these remain the same. For an ARMA model, we can do similar things. Fortunately, it is easy to do this in R. \hdashline

16.9 Lag Operator

The i-step lag operator (sometimes called the “backshift” operator), Bi, is defined by Bi⁢Xt=Xt-i.
We can define our AR(p) model in terms of this operator:

Xt=c+(∑i=1pϕi⁢Bi)⁢Xt+εt,
(1-∑i=1pϕi⁢Bi)⁢Xt=c+εt.

This helps us define the next type of model using first differences:

X1-X0,X2-X1,X3-X2,…
(1-B)⁢Xt=Xt-Xt-1.
This gives us another way of writing previous models. For example, the AR(1) model can be written as
(1-ϕ⁢B)⁢Xt=c+εt.

16.10 Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average Process (ARIMA)

An ARIMA model with integer parameters, p,d,q, ARIMA(p,d,q), is

(1-∑i=1pϕi⁢Bi)⁢(1-B)d⁢Xt = c+(1+∑i=1qθi⁢Bi)⁢εt,
    where ⁢εt∼i.i.d.Gε⁢(0,σε2),

where c,θ1,…,θq,σε2,ϕ1,…,ϕp are model parameters.
All of our models so far are contained in this model:

AR⁢(p) ⇔ ARIMA⁢(p,0,0),
MA⁢(q) ⇔ ARIMA⁢(0,0,q),
ARMA⁢(p,q) ⇔ ARIMA⁢(p,0,q).
“Integrated” comes from the the definition that a time series is integrated of order 0 if it admits a moving average representation with ∑_k=0^∞∣θ_k^2∣¡ ∞, where θ is the possibly infinite vector of moving average weights. This implies that the autocovariance is decaying to 0 sufficiently quickly. This is a necessary, but not sufficient condition for a stationary process. Therefore, all stationary processes are I⁢(0), but not all I⁢(0) processes are stationary.

Example 81
\hdashlineDemonstrate fitting in R: arima.r. \hdashline

16.11 Vector Autoregressive Models

A vector autoregressive model with parameter p, VAR(p) is:

X1,t = c1+∑i=1pϕ1,1,i⁢X1,t-i+…+∑i=1pϕ1,n,i⁢Xn,t-i+ε1,t,
⋮
Xn,t = cn+∑i=1pϕn,1,i⁢X1,t-i+…+∑i=1pϕn,n,i⁢Xn,t-i+εn,t.

where all εi,j∼i.i.d.Gε⁢(0,σε2).

Actually, this error structure is a simplified version of the full VAR model which has a covariance matrix to model dependence in the errors across the time series.

Suppose we have n time series:

1s⁢t⁢ time series: …,X1,0,X1,1,X1,2,…
2n⁢d⁢ time series: …,X2,0,X2,1,X2,2,…
⋮
nt⁢h⁢ time series: …,Xn,0,Xn,1,Xn,2,…

We could model {X1,t} using an AR(p) process:

X1,t=c1+∑i=1pϕ1,1,i⁢X1,t-i+ε1,t

We could model {Xr,t} using a separate AR(p) process:

Xr,t=cr+∑i=1pϕr,r,i⁢Xr,t-i+εr,t

What if we thought that X1,t depended on both its previous values and previous values from other time series? We could write:

X1,t=c1+∑i=1pϕ1,1,i⁢X1,t-i+∑i=1pϕ1,2,i⁢X2,t-i+…+∑i=1pϕ1,n,i⁢Xn,t-i+ε1,t.

We could then do this for all n time series simultaneously, and this is a VAR(p) model. Each time series is a constant plus a linear combination of its p previous values, and the p previous values from the other time series, plus error.

Remember: For ϕr,s,i, r is the index for the time series that you are modelling, s is the index of the time series that you are considering past values for and i is the number of ‘steps back’ that we are considering.

17 Modelling Time Series with Changing Variability (Brooks Ch 8)

The models we have looked at so far have been like:

Xt=constant+(coefficients×random variables)+white noise.

These do not help if the variance is changing over time.

17.1 Checking time series assumptions

Consider a simple AR(1) model: Xt=c+ϕ1⁢Xt-1+εt.
Apart from checking the acf and pacf are behaving correctly, we need to consider if εt∼i.i.d.Gε⁢(0,σε2) is appropriate.

Make link to checking the assumptions of a linear model.

Let’s say we have fitted a model in R using 𝚃𝚂𝚖𝚘𝚍𝚎𝚕=𝚊𝚛𝚒𝚖𝚊⁢(𝚍𝚊𝚝𝚊,𝚌⁢(𝟷,𝟶,𝟶)).
The error terms (or residuals, innovations), that are the difference between the fitted model and the observed data, are automatically stored in 𝚃𝚂𝚖𝚘𝚍𝚎𝚕⁢$⁡𝚛𝚎𝚜𝚒𝚍𝚞𝚊𝚕𝚜.
To assess if E⁢(εt) is appropriate, you might look at 𝚖𝚎𝚊𝚗⁢(…) or 𝚑𝚒𝚜𝚝⁢(…). To assess independence, we could plot the residuals against time, 𝚙𝚕𝚘𝚝⁢(…), or the autocorrelation in the residuals, 𝚊𝚌𝚏⁢(…). These plot can also tell us about variability of data over time.
 

Changing mean:    try ARIMA (looks at the differences),
Changing variance: try ARCH (fits model to the variance).

17.2 Returns and (Crude) Volatility

Note that there are several definitions for both of these

We have an observed time series:

x0,x1,…,xn.

We can create another time series by looking at differences at lag 1 (in R, use 𝚍𝚒𝚏𝚏⁢(…)).

x1-x0,x2-x1,…,xn-xn-1

In finance, we are often interested in a rescaled version of this given by the series of arithmetic returns:

r1,r2,…,rn,where⁢rt=xt-xt-1xt-1.

Example 82 \hdashlineThe price at close of BP stock was 417.0 and 423.1 over two consecutive days (6.1 gain). For G4S, the prices at the same time were 241.7 and 246.2 (4.5 gain). Return for BP: 423.1-417.0417.0 =0.0146 Return for G4S: 246.2-241.7241.7 =0.0186 \hdashline

Because the arithmetic return can change by orders of magnitude from day to day, the logarithmic returns are usually reported.

l⁢r1,l⁢r2,…,l⁢rn, where ⁢l⁢rt=ln⁢(xt)-ln⁢(xt-1)=ln⁢(xtxt-1).

One measure of volatility of a time series over n time steps is:

∑i=1n(l⁢ri-l⁢r¯)2(n-1)   (the sample variance for log returns).

If the variance of our time series is fixed over time, this volatility measure should be fixed over time. In a time series based on stock prices, we often see changes in volatility over time, and high volatility occurs in bursts. Further, low volatility over a period will (on average) lead to more low volatility, and high volatility will (on average) lead to more high volatility. This suggests correlation in volatility over time.

If variability is unchanged over time, we say that the time series model is homoscedastic. If variability changes over time, we say the time series model is heteroscedastic.

17.3 Autoregressive Conditional Heteroscedastic (ARCH) Model

An ARCH model is essentially two models: one for the mean behaviour and one for the variance. The typical set-up is to have an ARMA(p,q) for the mean behaviour and a separate model for the variance based on variances from previous time steps.

Recall that ARMA(p,q) is

Xt=c+εt+∑i=1pϕi⁢Xt-i+∑i=1qθi⁢εt-i

with independent εt|σt2∼Gε⁢(0,σt2). Now,

ARCH⁢(q*): σt2= α0+∑i=1q*αi⁢νt-i2,
νt= σt⁢zt,
where zt∼i.i.d. Gz⁢(0,1).

The parameters for this model are the ARMA parameters, plus α0,α1,…,αq* and σz2.
α0 is the expected variance over the time series;
α1,…,αq* tell us how related the current variance is to variances at previous timesteps;
σz2 tells us how far σt2 could move in time.
Essentially, the bigger the αi, the more volatile the time series, and the bigger σz2, the more heteroscedastic the time series.

Example 83 \hdashline The ARCH(1) model is given by σt2 = α0+α1⁢νt-12 νt2 = σt2⁢zt2=(α0+α1⁢νt-12)⁢zt2 with Var⁢[zt]=1 and E⁢[zt]=0. This is a bit like ar AR(1) process but in νt2 rather than νt, and with multiplicative noise with a mean of 1, rather than additive noise with a mean of zero. We have E⁢[νt2∣νt,…] = E⁢{(α0+α1⁢νt-12)⁢zt2∣νt-1,νt-2,…} = α0+α1⁢νt-12⁢E⁢(zt2∣νt-1,νt-2,…) = α0+α1⁢νt-12 If νt-1 has a large (absolute) value, the σt is larger than usual, and so νt is also expected to have an unusually large magnitude. This volatility propagates since when νt has large deviation, then σt+12 is large and so on. Similarly for small values. So, unusually large volatility in νt tends to persist, though not forever. \hdashline

Say something about model fitting: point to tomorrow’s practical? And mention fGarch for fitting in R (fGARCH stands for family GARCH which encompasses most of the GARCH variants).

17.4 Generalised Autoregressive Conditional Heteroscedastic (GARCH) Model

This is the same as ARCH, but with a MA process as well as the AR process for σt2.

The GARCH(p*,q*) model is thus defined by

νt = σt⁢zt,
σt2 = ω+∑i=1p*αi⁢νt-12+∑j=1q*βj⁢σk-j2,

where ω>0,αi≥0,βj≥0, and the innovation sequence zt is i.i.d. with E⁢[zt]=0 and Var⁢[zt]=1.
